content: Titel: Level 1 - Module 2 - Understanding Human Anatomy URL: https://web.lemon-mobile-learning.com/hyrox/#/inhalt/18104 Chapter: Understanding Human Anatomy in Relation to Human Movement Hey coaches, let's dive into an introduction to human anatomy and how it relates to movement. Our bodies are incredible feats of engineering, capable of executing a wide range of movements with precision and efficiency. This capability largely stems from the complex interaction between our muscles, bones, and nervous system, a relationship that forms the backbone of functional anatomy. Understanding this interaction is vital for every Hiro coach. With a solid grasp of functional anatomy, you'll understand why certain movements and exercises are more effective than others. You also discover how to optimize your training to engage multiple muscle groups and other crucial body structures like the elastic recall system and complex movements, helping you and your athletes achieve their athletic goals. So let's dive right in. Chapter: Functional Anatomy and Biomechanicsin context of HYROX – the sport of Fitness Racing Functional anatomy and kinetics play a crucial role not only in traditional athletic training and competition, but also in emerging fitness disciplines like functional fitness or hybrid training and sports such as HYROX - the World Series of Fitness Racing. Functional fitness training, characterized by exercises mimicking real-life movements, heavily relies on an understanding of Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics. Coaches design workouts targeting multiple muscle groups simultaneously by understanding the body's movement in various planes and under different loads. This improves overall functional strength and mobility. Special exercises are chosen for functional fitness routines because they engage multiple joints and muscle groups, reflecting functional anatomy's principles. Within HYROX, the Sport of Fitness Racing, which combines functional fitness exercises with running, Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics are key for both training and performance optimization. Competitors must navigate functional fitness challenges, such as Sled Push and Pull, Burpee Broad Jump or Sandbag Lunges as well as RowErg, SkiErg, WallBalls or Farmers Carries, interspersed with running segments. Understanding these movements' biomechanics is vital for efficient execution and energy conservation. In HYROX racing, knowledge of Biomechanics is particularly relevant, as athletes constantly adapt to shifting external forces during dynamic movements. For instance, during a Sled Push, athletes must generate sufficient force to propel the sled forward while maintaining stability and balance. Understanding efficient force application and momentum usage can make the difference between a competitive time and fatigue-induced slowdowns. In both functional fitness training and HYROX racing, a thorough understanding of Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics allows coaches to tailor training programs to enhance performance and reduce injury risk. Trainers can prescribe corrective exercises and drills to address specific needs by identifying movement patterns, imbalances, and areas of weakness, ultimately optimizing athletic potential. In conclusion, Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics are integral to both traditional athletic endeavors and modern fitness disciplines like functional fitness training and sports such as HYROX racing. By embracing these principles, coaches can enhance the performance of their athletes, reduce injury risk, and achieve greater success.

content: Titel: Level 1 - Module 2 - Bone physiology URL: https://web.lemon-mobile-learning.com/hyrox/#/inhalt/18106 Chapter: Bone Physiology Bone consists of a mixture of water, protein and mineral salts, the latter of which constitutes roughly 50% of its structure. Bone strength is the result of a combination of the hardness of these minerals combined with the tensile properties of collagen (derived from protein). Too little of one (e.g. collagen) and the bone will shatter like an egg shell; too little of the other (e.g. mineral salts) and bone will bend like a piece of rubber. 25% water, 25% protein, 50% mineral salts Chapter: Ossification - The Process of Bone Formation Although bone is rigid, it behaves like any other living tissue; it is constantly being broken down, rebuilt and adapting to the stresses placed on it. The process of bone formation is called ossification which begins in the womb and continues throughout adult life. The hardening and growth process involves replacing a cartilage ‘framework’ with mineral salts. Bones of young children are softer than those of adults because they still contain significant proportions of cartilage. The hardening process may not be complete until 30 years of age. So, in early life, the emphasis of ossification is very much on bone growth and bone hardening, whereas the process in adulthood is more geared towards replacing and maintaining existing bone material. Whilst there is quite a diversity of cells involved in the bone formation process, the primary cells involved in bone growth are osteoblasts, which function to replace worn out or damaged bone tissue. Their activity is coordinated with that of the osteoclast cells, which remove the old bony tissue. Maintenance of a healthy skeletal system is dependent upon a balance of osteoblast and osteoclast activity. This can vary according to the region of bone concerned; the end of the femur, for example, can be completely remodeled every few months, which contrasts with the bone shafts which may never be fully remodeled. It is also worth noting that remodeling will tend to follow the lines of stress placed upon the bone. Exercise and habitual posture therefore, have a fundamental influence over the health of the skeletal system. Incorrect exercise technique coupled with a generally poor alignment, will lead to a remodeling process that may reinforce the predominating bad posture. Chapter: Hormonal Regulation Of Bone In the pre-puberty years, bone formation is predominantly regulated by human growth hormone (HGH) produced by the pituitary gland located in the brain. At puberty however, testosterone produced by the male testes and estrogen produced by the female ovaries begin to exert a greater influence. In women, estrogen promotes growth of the skeleton and development of the unique female skeletal characteristics (i.e. the broader pelvis). Testosterone on the other hand, causes males to have larger, denser and more robust skeletons. Chapter: The Skeletal System And Calcium Regulation Although calcium provides the skeletal system with rigidity it is also involved in several other important functions. These include muscular contraction, transmission of nervous impulses and regulating fluid balance. Too much or too little calcium in the body can easily upset these processes, thus bones act as calcium reservoirs which can either take up or release calcium depending on the body’s needs. When calcium is scarce, it will be withdrawn from the bones, which is why diets that are chronically low in calcium tend to increase the risk of osteoporosis – a bone-related medical condition characterized by brittle, porous bones. Chapter: Osteoporosis (Brittle Bone Disease) Bone remodeling is a delicate balance of osteoblast and osteoclast activity. Osteoporosis is caused by an imbalance in this process whereby osteoblast activity decreases causing a reduction in bone growth. This leads to a gradual loss in bone density and ultimately gives rise to a skeletal system that is unable to withstand the forces placed upon it. There are several potential causes of osteoporosis however one of the biggest is the drop in estrogen levels associated with the menopause. This makes women significantly more likely to develop the condition than men. In men, a proportion of circulating testosterone (which is produced throughout life) is converted into estrogen and this is thought to provide men with significant protection against loss of bone mass. Additionally, men have bigger, denser bones in the first place, so some bone loss is not as noticeable or as damaging. Low calorific intake and/or overtraining also increase the risk of osteoporosis in females by depleting body fat stores which are one of the primary sources of estrogen. Poor quality diets which are lacking in or have an imbalance of minerals and vitamins also increase the risks by limiting the availability of calcium. The table below provides a summary of some of the risk factors associated with osteoporosis. Osteoporosis risk factors: female sex – due to drop in estrogen levels (particularly at the menopause) calcium deficiency – through poor diet or poor absorption lack of weight-bearing exercise smoking – causes a drop in estrogen levels family history certain drugs, such as alcohol which interrupt normal hormonal and calcium regulation low body fat overtraining Chapter: The Classification And Structure Of Bone Bone tissue varies in arrangement and depending on its location and functions, comes in two main forms; compact and cancellous. Compact bone has a relatively high density of bone matter. It forms the external surfaces of bones, predominates in the shafts of long bones and serves to resist compressive forces. It is very strong and quite heavy. Cancellous bone, in comparison, is relatively more porous and if viewed closely has a spongy appearance. It predominates in the interior of bones and especially at bone ends (epiphyses). The spaces within the cancellous bone form a vital function by housing red marrow, which is responsible for red blood cell production. Cancellous bone, because of its honey-combe structure is strong but is also light. Bones can be classified according to their shape and will generally fall into one of five shape categories; long, short, flat, irregular and sesamoid: 1. Long bones – have a greater length than width and consist of a shaft with normally two extremities. They contain mostly cancellous bone in their distal ends and more compact bone in their middles. They principally act as levers and include the humerus, femur, fibula, tibia, ulna, radius, metacarpals, metatarsals and phalanges. 2. Short bones – have a cubed appearance and are predominantly cancellous bone with an outer shell of compact bone. These include the carpals (except for the pisiform – which is sesamoid) and the tarsals (except for the calcaneus which is irregular). 3. Flat bones – thin cancellous bone sandwiched between two compact layers affording protection or large areas for muscle attachment. Examples of these are the scapula, cranial bones, costals (ribs), sternum and ilium. 4. Irregular – form complex shapes and cannot be classified in the other groups. The vertebrae are considered to be irregular and contain varying proportions of compact and cancellous bone. 5. Sesamoid – meaning seed-like, these bones develop within particular tendons at a site of friction or tension. They serve to reduce wear and tear in the tendon and increase leverage of muscle by moving the tendon away from the fulcrum. Examples include the patella (kneecap) and pisiform (carpal bone). Although there are different classifications of bones, a closer analysis of a long bone is useful as it helps highlight many of the properties and functions of the skeletal system. The diagram below shows a cross section of a typical long bone (in this case the humerus). Epiphysis - the bone ends, which are mainly comprised of cancellous bone, and house much of the red marrow involved in red blood cell production. They are also one of the primary sites for bone growth, and during growth periods can be quite vulnerable to breakage. Diaphysis - is the shaft portion of a long bone, and in comparison, to the bone ends is predominantly compact bone (although the inside of the shaft is hollow). The principal role of the diaphysis is support. Epiphyseal plates - are part of the region connecting the diaphysis to the epiphysis. It is a layer of subdividing cartilaginous cells where growth in length of the diaphysis occurs. Multiplying cartilaginous cells are arranged like columns of coins which move towards the diaphysis, becoming more calcified as they go. Osteoblasts will eventually complete the process of bone formation. When adults finish growing the plates will harden and ‘close’, no further growth will take place. If the plates are damaged before growth has finished, then this may result in a shorter bone. However, that little evidence exists that exercise has any effect on bone length in children. Instead it is more likely to lead to broader stronger bones (provided it is accompanied with appropriate diet). Periosteum – this forms a tough fibrous membrane which coats the bone. It contains nerves, blood vessels and bone producing cells. Its inner surface provides the materials for repair and facilitates growth in the diameter of the bone. It also plays a fundamental role in movement by providing the point of attachment for tendons. Medullary cavity – is a space which runs down through the centre of the diaphysis. This contains fatty, yellow marrow which is predominantly composed of adipose tissue, and serves as a useful energy reserve. Articular (hyaline) cartilage – the ends of articulating bones are covered with articular or hyaline cartilage. It is a hard, white shiny tissue which, along with synovial fluid, helps reduce friction in freely moveable (synovial joints). It is fundamental for smooth joint action.

When you exhale it relaxes and moves back upwards. The illustration shows a superior view of the diaphragm, the primary muscle used in the process of breathing. Every time you breathe, which is upwards of 20,000 times a day and might even be 30,000 or 40,000 times during a HYROX competition, a tug of war begins between the right and left sides of the diaphragm. Up until now, you would have assumed that they are pulling with equal strength. But now that you’re taking the time to educate yourself, you might realize that they are not, The right diaphragm is much stronger than the left. The frontal view of the diaphragm highlights its dome-shaped structure, which forms a crucial partition between the thoracic and abdominal cavities. By training in a way that enhances gait mechanics, HYROX athletes can improve their overall movement efficiency, endurance, and power. The sport's emphasis on real-world movements means that the benefits extend beyond the gym, improving everyday activities and overall quality of life. In summary, HYROX is a great sport and training concept because it aligns with the body's anatomical asymmetries and natural biomechanics, emphasizing unilateral strength and functional movement. This not only enhances athletic performance but also promotes balanced strength and reduces the risk of injury. He lived with me, an MLB Strength and Conditioning Coach, and each day, we would head to the gym to train together! In the beginning of the offseason, I asked him what his goals were for the next season so I could build our workouts around that. “I want to throw over 100 miles-per-hour!” he exclaimed, “I’m not talking about just 100, I want 101, 102!” I’m pretty sure I laughed out loud when he said that. He already threw about 98mph. He was already a flamethrower. I knew that to get someone from 98 to 101 is crazy hard. There are so few human beings capable of generating that level of power and when you already throw 98, you’re pretty much using everything you’ve got already. But I started to think about the system I had been secretly building to try and unleash every ounce of my own players’ athletic potential. I needed to put this system to the test. I started to think that maybe, just maybe, if I can press the right buttons, and put together a masterpiece of a workout plan, I might be able to make it happen. So, I decided to challenge myself and see what I could come up with. We called it “Operation genMAX.” Which was short for “Genetic Max” because our goal was to tap into every last drop of genetic, god-given power that he had…we knew we would need all of it. I threw the kitchen sink at him. We did all of my brain-training techniques to make sure his brain was allowing him complete access to his power and potential. (Stay tuned in to Level 2 of the HYROX365 Academy for more information on this). We trained super specific muscles to maximize his power and speed. And we focused in on only one energy-production system. The same one that Usain Bolt used to set the world-record in the 100-meter dash. For the entire offseason, we put in the work. He was fully committed to his goal and he trusted that I had the skills to help him get there. That spring, we both hopped on planes to go to Spring Training and we hoped for the best. Well, just a few weeks into Spring Training, I looked down at my phone and saw he had sent me a text. I picked up my phone, opened the message and it said… “You’re never going to believe what just happened. They clocked me today at 102 mph.” Even I was shocked! I knew my programs were good, but 102 mph seemed so unrealistic. Only a tiny few people in the world, who have genetically given superpowers, can throw that hard! It’s so rare that the media started to report about it and once it got onto Twitter, my players in Arizona started seeing the news too. The next day, players from throughout the organization were asking me to create their programs. Most of these guys had other Strength Coaches they worked with, but that didn’t matter, they wanted the fuel! They wanted the secret stuff, and they knew I had the secrets! But what I really had was a better understanding of gait mechanics. If you look at the way a baseball player throws a baseball, a right- handed pitcher will stand tall on their right foot, drive off of the mound and transition from standing on their right leg to standing on their left. This is gait. This is a dynamix expression of gait mechanics, as they need to be able to seamlessly transfer their weight and they need to do it while being explosive and under control. The most critical component of Operation genMAX was ensuring that I wasn’t compromising his already beautiful gait mechanics. Therefore, my mission was to make his gait mechanics more powerful. What is Gait? Gait = Walking; gait is just a fancy way of saying “walking”. Every system and function of the body operates through gait mechanics. Like I have written before, even the way your body wiggles food down your esophagus works through gait mechanics. It is the absolute top of the functional pyramid. When you hear someone talking about “functional fitness,” if they aren’t directly referring to gait mechanics, it simply isn’t functional. The entire body operates under the laws of gait. A Deeper Look at Gait Mechanics Let’s imagine someone walking through the park. Beneath the surface there is a symphony of muscle activity taking place. When the heel of the right foot strikes the ground, it sends the signal to the brain to turn on the muscles of right single leg stance. In right single leg stance the body weight is shifted off of the left and on to the right. To accomplish this, the muscles of right single leg stance must turn on and the muscles of left single leg stance must turn off. Once your body weight is over your right leg and you are squarely in right single leg stance, there’s no time to rest. Next, you’ll immediately begin to transition your weight over to your left side. Your left heel strikes the floor which, as you now know, signals the muscles of left single leg stance to turn on while simultaneously shutting off the muscles of right single leg stance. This is gait mechanics at a high level. Right Stance…Left Stance… Right Stance…Left Stance…Right Stance…Left Stance… This is how the body propels you forward. Dynamic Expression of Gait When we look at sports, like the example I gave above about a baseball pitcher, you can see gait mechanics come alive in a big, fun way. A pitcher standing tall on his right leg, pushing off of the mound and driving all of his weight and power to his left is a really powerful way of demonstrating gait mechanics. Most sports are exactly that. Baseball and Golf are really simple and obvious examples of this. If you think of a golfer, they take their club back and load their back leg before unleashing all their power as they transition from one stance-leg to the other. If I were to train a golfer, I would want them to be able to express as much power as possible within the confines of quality gait mechanics. When we break down a HYROX race, we see gait everywhere! Heck, 50% of the race is running! The Sled Push; the Sled Pull; Sandbag Lunges; Farmers Carries; Burpee Broad Jumps with the Step-Up- Technique. Damn near the whole race is a battle of your ability to maintain gait under duress. When I first started training for HYROX, my first mission was to build enough strength so that I could move the sleds. In my first week of training, I bench-pressed the 90lbs dumbbells. What did I do next? I immediately scrapped the program. “I’m strong enough”, I said to myself. I don’t need to spend another second getting stronger. I need to spend the rest of my prep time applying volume and endurance to my gait mechanics. To perform at the absolute highest level in a HYROX race, the muscles of gait must be capable of meeting the demands of HYROX otherwise the body will resort to less functional and less powerful compensatory muscles. Our mission then, is to train the gait mechanics of your athletes to last for the entire race. If you can do that, which you absolutely can, you will be pushing your athletes onto the podium. Chapter: The Big 3 - The Most Important Muscles to Train I’ve worked with 6-foot-9 NBA players who can jump 45 inches in the air. I’ve worked with Olympians who are quite literally the best in the world. But without a doubt, the best athletes I’ve ever worked with are professional baseball pitchers. More specifically, the ones who can throw absolute fireballs. I’m talking about the guys who are throwing 100mph+. These guys have everything working. They are perfect specimens. The beauty of working with a professional baseball team is that I got to see guys who were trying as hard as they could, but couldn’t throw any faster than 88 mph. Then I would work with guys who looked like they were barely trying and the ball would explode out of their hands and crash into the catcher’s mitt at 102 mph. What was the difference between these two types of pitchers? Glutes, Hamstrings, Adductors and Obliques! These are the prime movers of gait. The Prime Movers of Gait The muscles of gait are truly head-to-toe. Muscles as big as the glutes and hamstrings as well as tiny muscles like the lateral pterygoid in your jaw all have a role when it comes to gait and propelling the body forward. Most coaches will never need to know a damn thing about the lateral pterygoid. But EVERY coach needs to be incredibly proficient at training the prime movers of gait: The Glute Max The Hamstrings (all 3) The Adductor Magnus The Obliques (Transversus Abdominis and Internal Obliques) The reason we want to focus on these muscles is because they have all the leverage to move the skeleton. Take a look at the two images below. The first image is a picture of the rectus abdominis. This is a great example of what I’m talking about. Everyone wants the rectus abdominis. This is your six-pack muscle. But as you can see, it only has a few tiny attachment sites. When we compare it to the obliques, you can see the difference between the Rectus and the massive attachment sites of the abdominal obliques. The four prime movers of gait are the lowest hanging fruit. The ones that will give you the most bang for your buck. What did those flamethrowing pitchers have that everyone else didn’t? Big, juicy glutes, hamstrings, adductors and obliques. It was no coincidence that they could all easily dunk a basketball anytime they wanted. The Glute Max The primary role of the glute max in gait mechanics is to push you from one leg to the next. When I reach my left leg out in front of me while walking and being the weight transfer from my right leg to my left, the glute max is in charge of driving that transfer. The Hamstrings The primary role of the hamstrings in gait is hip extension. When your heel contacts the ground, it activates the hamstring which drives the heel back through the ground, thus propelling the body forward. The Adductor Magnus When your body weight shifts to the left during left single leg stance, it’s assisted by the adductor magnus (which is sometimes referred to as the fourth hamstring). Think about a supermodel walking down the runway. They usually have an exaggerated hip shift. Their hips pop from side to side. The adductor is the puppet master here. The Obliques The obliques are the glue that hold the upper body (ribs) and pelvis together. Like I mentioned above, the muscles of gait range from head to toe. The obliques serve as the first stop up the chain from the lower body. Building Training Programs 100% of the training programs I have built over the last decade have revolved around these muscles. Even when I work on conditioning, I am specifically trying to condition these muscles. It has become a right of passage for the clients I work with to have really sore hamstrings, glutes, adductors and abs after their first session. When they get together, I revel in the war stories they tell each other about them. These muscles are everywhere on my programs. Other muscles are mostly nowhere to be found. These are the muscles that really matter. When you build training programs, there is a lot of information you must weigh. There is no shortage of warm-up drills, exercises and modalities. There’s enough to make your training session last for 15 hours. Your job is to prioritize what’s most important and after a decade of experience working with the highest performers on the planet, I can say without a shadow of a doubt that your highest priorities should be getting these muscles working like absolute machines. We were sitting up on some rooftop restaurant at the Bacara Resort in Santa Barbara, California. This is where we, the Los Angeles Lakers, were staying during the 2016 Training Camp (which was being held at UC Santa Barbara). Our General Manager, Mitch Kupchak, walked over to our table where the training staff was eating to talk about our newest rookie, the 6-foot-9 standout from Duke University and #2 overall pick in the draft, Brandon Ingram. Brandon was skinny. Very skinny and the obvious concerns with him was whether he would be able to sustain the physicality of the NBA. A common comparison was Kevin Durant, but it’s hard to compare a first-year rookie, with a sure-fire hall of famer. Mitch wanted to talk about putting more muscle on the young rookie. Reports were swirling out of Philadelphia, where their skinny rookie, Ben Simmons, had apparently gained upwards of twenty pounds since being drafted. This put some added pressure onto our Strength and Conditioning Staff to perform. The problem was, we knew that wasn’t going to happen. We knew we couldn’t just throw 20 pounds on this frame. We knew he would likely be “skinny” his whole career (and his whole life for that matter). He just had that “ectomorph” body type, whereas Simmons had more of a mesomorph frame. Technically, we could get him to gain weight, but it would only slow him down and make him less athletic. We were faced with a judgment call. We knew what the organization REALLY wanted. They wanted a great and CONSISTENT basketball player, and we knew we could deliver that, just not the way they had in mind. The problem with any NBA player is that, not only are they pushing their own physical limitations as to how high they can jump and how fast they can run. But they are pushing the very limits of humans. Brandon is 6-foot-9, runs like a deer and jumps 40 inches in the air. To get him to jump 41 inches or run slightly faster, it takes a massive effort and significant appreciation to the details. When you read about all the benefits of exercising, you’re reading about exercise in general. For the average couch potato, yes, it is helpful for them to do literally anything fitness related: Zumba Pilates Yoga Going for a Walk Basic Weightlifting Bodyweight Squats But for elite athlete, Brandon Ingram, I don’t think he would get much out of that Zumba class. Congratulations! You’ve arrived! This is a big moment in your career! This is the moment that you cross the threshold from general fitness to elite performance. No longer will the basics suffice. You must now commit to knowing the ins and outs of the human body better than anyone else. This is what it takes to train the best.

content: Titel: Level 1 - Module 2 - Anatomical Structures and Roles of Tendons and Ligaments in Human Movement URL: https://web.lemon-mobile-learning.com/hyrox/#/inhalt/18110 Chapter: Tendons and Ligaments Tendons and ligaments are crucial components of the musculoskeletal system, playing vital roles in human movement, stability, and overall biomechanics. Despite their similar appearances, these structures have distinct anatomical features and functions that contribute to the efficient functioning of the body. Hey, HYROX coaches. Let's talk about tendons, the unsung heroes of our muscular system. These tough fibrous tissues are like the body's bungee cords connecting our muscles to our bones. Picture tendons as super strong rubber bands made mostly of collagen fibers. These fibers are arranged in neat parallel bundles, kind of like a well organized cable system. This structure is what gives tendons their superpower, the ability to transmit force from muscles to bones with incredible efficiency. Now, why are tendons so crucial for our hierar athletes? Well, they are the key players in transforming muscle contractions into actual movement. Take the Achilles tendon, for example. It connects our calves to our heel bone, allowing us to push off the ground during those grueling runs and jumps in high rocks. But wait, there's more. Tenants aren't just passive connectors, they are also energy savers. During dynamic movements like the 1K runs in between the high rock stations with the right running technique, tenants can actually store and release energy. It's like having a built in spring system, helping our athletes to move more efficiently and conserve energy throughout the competition. By focusing on exercise that strengthen both muscles and their connecting tendons, we can help our athletes perform better and potentially reduce their risk of injury. Remember, in the world of hiros, every bit of efficiency counts. Now let's turn our attention to ligaments, the unsung heroes of our joints. These tough fibrous bands are like the security guards of our skeletal system, connecting bones to other bones and keeping everything in check. Picture ligaments as flexible yet strong ropes made mostly of collagen fibers. Unlike the neat parallel arrangement and tendons, ligament fibers are more freestyle in their layout. This unique structure is what gives the ligaments their superpower, the ability to provide stability in multiple directions. Now, why are ligaments so crucial for our hiar athletes? Well, they are the bodyguards of our joints, setting limits on how far they can move. Take the anterior cruciate ligament or ACL in the knee. It's like a bouncer preventing the tibia from sliding too far forward relative to the femur. But wait, there's more. ligaments aren't just passive restraints. They are equipped with tiny sensors called mechcono receptors. These little guys are constantly feeding information to our nervous system about the position and movement of our joints. It's like having a built in GPS for our body, helping us maintain balance and coordination throughout the hiros course. By respecting these crucial structures and working to strengthen the muscle around them, we can help our Hiro competitors perform at their peak while minimizing the risk of injury. Remember, in the world of HYROX, every little bit of stability counts. Chapter: Role of Tendons and Ligaments in Human Movement Both tendons and ligaments are integral to human movement and overall musculoskeletal health. Tendons ensure that the force generated by muscles is effectively transmitted to bones, enabling movement. Without tendons, muscles would not be able to produce the necessary leverage to move the skeletal system. Ligaments, by providing joint stability, ensure that movements are executed within a safe range, preventing injuries such as dislocations and sprains. In addition to their mechanical roles, tendons and ligaments also play a part in sensory feedback. The mechanoreceptors within these structures send information to the brain about joint position and movement, contributing to proprioception and the body's ability to perform complex, coordinated movements. In summary, tendons and ligaments are fundamental to the functionality and efficiency of the musculoskeletal system. Tendons connect muscles to bones, allowing for the transfer of force and facilitating movement, while ligaments connect bones to other bones, providing joint stability and preventing excessive movement. Together, these structures ensure that the body can perform a wide range of movements with precision and stability, highlighting their essential roles in human movement and biomechanics. Joints, cartilage, and tendons also play crucial roles in human movement. Joints are, as you have learned before, the points where two or more bones meet, allowing for movement and providing support. Cartilage cushions the joints and helps reduce friction, while tendons attach muscles to bones and transmit the force produced by the muscles.

We'll examine the structure and function of the human body and how they interact to create movement. This knowledge will help in designing effective training programs and improving performance. Anatomy studies the structure of living organisms, focusing on identifying and describing body parts, organs, and tissues. It provides a detailed understanding of the body's physical makeup, including bones, muscles, nerves, and blood vessels. Functional Anatomy goes further by examining how these structures work together to produce movement and perform functions. For example, while anatomy describes the position and appearance of a muscle, functional anatomy looks at how that muscle contributes to movement, interacts with other muscles and structures in the body, and adapts during physical activity. The main difference between Anatomy and Functional Anatomy is their focus: Anatomy emphasizes structure, while Functional Anatomy emphasizes the relationship between structure and function. In this module, alongside our exploration of Anatomy and Functional Anatomy, we will delve into the study of Biomechanics. Joints allow movement but not all joints are moveable. Exercise can help keep joints strong and healthy and knowing which muscles control which joints will make exercise prescription much easier. There are several different types of joints. Fibrous (immovable) joints – these represent some of the most rigid of the joints, such as the cranial joints. The cranial bones interlock with one another and are bound together with fibrous connective tissue. They possess high levels of stability but lack the ability for movement. Cartilaginous (slightly movable) joints – in these types of joint there is some limited potential for movement. Articulating bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include, the pubis symphysis and between the vertebral bodies. In contrast to the fibrous joints described above, they provide moderate stability and some limited movement. Synovial (freely moveable) joints – these joints allow the large movements we associate with exercise and consequently they will be discussed in more detail. Synovial joints come in a variety of different configurations which allow different types of movement. They do, however, all share several characteristics. Chapter: The Anatomy of a Synovial Joint Unlike the other forms of joint, the synovial joint has no connective tissue joining the articulating surfaces. Instead, there is a joint space and the ends of the bones are covered with a form of cartilage (hyaline cartilage) which serves to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and provide some shock absorption. Bony surfaces are held together by a fibrous articular joint capsule which is flexible enough to allow plenty of movement but tough enough to support the joint where necessary. Sections of the joint capsule may thicken and form ligaments which provide additional support to the joint. On the inner surface of the articular capsule is a synovial membrane which secretes a lubricant called synovial fluid. Synovial fluid has the consistency of uncooked egg white and is more viscous (thick) when the joint is inactive – fluidity and production of this lubricant increases as activity increases. Synovial fluid serves to help lubricate the joint surfaces and provides nutrients to the articular cartilage, which has a poor blood supply and is white in colour. Welcome back, everybody. Now, let's take a closer look into the fascinating world of synovial joints. These joints, though sharing fundamental features, exhibit a wide range of structures and movements. We can broadly categorize them into six main types, ball and socket, hinge, pivot, gliding, saddle, and ellipsoid joints. Let's start with the ball and socket joint. This type allows for movement in nearly any direction, making it incredibly versatile. You'll find these joints in the hips and shoulders. Moving on to the pivot joint, this joint type permits rotation around an axis. For instance, in your neck, the atlas and axis vertebra form a pivot joint, enabling head rotation. In the forearm, the radius and ulna create a pivot joint allowing for supination and pronation movements. Then there's the gliding joint where the articulating surfaces are typically flat, allowing for simple sliding movements. Ligaments limit these movements to forward, backward, and side to side. You'll find gliding joints in areas like between the patella and femur, the carpets and tarsals, and the acromium process and clavicle. Now let's talk about the saddle joint, which resembles one saddle sitting atop another. This joint allows for back and forth and up and down movements, but not rotation like a ball and socket joint. A prime example is the joint at the base of your thumb between the metacarpal and the trapezium. Finally, we have the ellipsoe joint, similar to the ball and socket joint, but more oval shaped. This structure limits movement to side to side and back and forth. You'll find ellipsoid joints in the wrists between the radius and carpals and between the metacarpals and phalanges. Understanding these joint types help us appreciate how our bodies move and adapt, supporting a wide range of activities from simple daily tasks to high performance sports.

content: Titel: Level 1 - Module 2 - The Vertebral Column URL: https://web.lemon-mobile-learning.com/hyrox/#/inhalt/18108 Chapter: The Vertebral Column Hello, coaches, let's examine the vertebral column, also known as the spine or backbone in close detail. This incredible structure is a cornerstone of our body's support system and plays a crucial role in movement. The vertebral column is not just a stack of bones, it's a marvel of engineering that provides central support for our body and facilitates a wide range of movements. In Hiros, this becomes particularly important. But that's not all. The vertebral column also serves as a protective housing for our spinal cord, which is vital for distributing nerves throughout the body. First, let's consider the structure. The spine consists of 33 individual vertebrae spread across 5 distinct sections cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacrum and coccyx. Each section plays a unique role in our movement. Now let's break down the structure from top to bottom. First, we have the cervical region in the neck consisting of 7 vertebrae. Next is the thoracic or chest section, which has 12 vertebrae. Moving down, we reach the lumbar region in the lower back, made up of 5 vertebrae. Then we have the sacrum, which contains 5 fused vertebrae. And finally at the base of the spine, we find the coccyx or tailbone composed of 4 vertebrae. Interestingly, there's quite a bit of variation between individuals when it comes to the number of vertebrae. Some people may have extra vertebrae in certain regions and fewer in others. However, the cervical region tends to be the most consistent across individuals. Understanding the structure and function of the vertebral column and its crucial role in human movement is important for hierarchs. You may ask why that is. Well, think about the variety of movements in a hierar competition from the ski arc to the wall balls, each discipline requires a different engagement of the spine. For example, during the sled push, your spine needs to maintain a strong, stable position to transfer force effectively from your legs to the sled. On the other hand, during the burpee broad jumps, your spine needs to be mobile enough to allow for the quick transition between positions. But here's where it really gets interesting. The vertebral column doesn't work in isolation. It's part of a complex system involving muscle, tendons, and fascia. This system allows for the efficient transfer of force throughout your body, which is crucial in high intensity sport like Hros. We dive deeper into this part later in our module. Understanding this interplay can help you optimize your training programs and performance. For instance, by focusing on exercise that improves spinal stability and mobility, you can enhance your efficiency in movements like the farmer's carry or the wallboards. Please remember, a well functioning vertebral column is not just about preventing injuries, although that's certainly important. It's about allowing your body to move as a cohesive unit, maximizing your power output and endurance across all highro disciplines. So as you prepare for your next Harrock competition or training session, take a moment to appreciate the incredible role your spine is playing. By understanding and respecting its function, you can unlock new levels of performance and truly embody the spirit of functional fitness that Hro represents. Chapter: The Anatomy of a Vertebra and Vertebral Disc Before considering the different regions of the spine in more detail, it is important to examine an individual vertebra more closely. Whilst differing considerably between regions, the vertebrae share the same basic anatomical features. The diagram above shows a typical vertebra. To the anterior (the front) is the main vertebral body, which is a cylindrical bony disc. This provides the surface for the intervertebral discs to attach to and these form the main cartilaginous joints of the spine. To the posterior (the back) are a series of bony projections (processes) which interlink with adjacent vertebra to form synovial facet joints. A series of openings or foramen punctuate the vertebra. These allow nerves and blood vessels to pass though the vertebral column. The intervertebral discs are sandwiched between the bodies of neighboring vertebrae. They are composed of a fibrocartilage shell that surrounds a softer gel-like core. Their primary function is shock absorption however, they are vulnerable to injury if the spine is excessively loaded with poor alignment or if the back is held in a chronically poor posture (i.e. sitting at a desk with a rounded back). Chapter: Posture Deviation from optimal spinal posture can be common. Pregnancy can increase curvature of the lower spine to shift the centre of gravity backwards and compensate for the extra weight at the front. Postural abnormality can be present at birth or can occur at any stage of life and can be temporary or permanent. Long periods of sitting, for example, can increase the chances of developing hyper kyphosis – the rounding of the upper back. While it is important to be able to recognise these postural abnormalities and it may be necessary for a personal trainer to work around them; correcting such issues is the job of a physical therapist. Lordosis - the spine curves significantly inward at the lower back Kyphosis- characterised by an abnormally rounded upper back Scoliosis- a sideways curve which is often s- shaped or c-shaped Identifying optimum posture can be tricky as clothing and other parts of the anatomy may obscure the vertebral column. However, if a line can be dropped vertically from the ear through the middle of the shoulder and hip to a point just in front of the ankle, then posture is probably correct. Chapter: Anatomical and functional variations in the vertebral column Whilst it is noted above that the vertebra have the same basic features, there are considerable anatomical and functional variations between the different regions of the spine. These are summarized in the table below: Region No. of Key Features Cervical 7 the smallest of the vertebrae facilitates movement of the head contains larger and a greater number of openings (foramen) to accommodate nerves and blood vessels Thoracic 12 forms joints with the costal bones capable of relatively more rotation than the lumbar vertebrae Lumbar 5 the largest vertebrae, to support greater loads capable of relatively more flexion, extension and lateral flexion than the thoracic vertebrae Sacrum 5 forms a joint with the pelvis usually fully fused by the age of 30 years Coccyx 4 the lowest section of the vertebral column usually fused by the age of 30

Chapter: Types of Muscle Tissue The human bony contains over 600 muscles but muscle tissue makes up more than just your biceps and triceps. Muscle tissue is found in three distinct forms. 1.Smooth muscle Smooth muscle is the most widely distributed and it predominates in the internal tissues of the body, including the digestive, circulatory, urinary and reproductive systems. One of its major functions is to regulate the diameter of tubular structures, thus enabling the body to control blood flow and blood pressure, the passage of food down the digestive tract and even the amount of light entering the eye. Control of this form of muscle is involuntary and is exerted via the autonomic system. 2.Cardiac muscle (myocardium) Cardiac muscle is found only in the heart but, like smooth muscle, is also under involuntary control. The unique feature of cardiac muscle is that it possesses the capability of self-excitation. In other words, it will continue to contract even if completely separated from the rest of the body (for a short time at least). The autonomic system exerts some control over cardiac muscle by both increasing or decreasing heart rate and the strength of contractions. This is examined more closely in the cardiovascular chapter. 3.Skeletal muscle Skeletal muscles are attached from bone-to-bone across joints, and are the main focus of this chapter. Unlike cardiac and smooth muscle, skeletal muscle is predominantly under voluntary control via the somatic nervous system. Skeletal muscle has a number of functions such as: Producing movement Stabilizing body positions i.e. maintenance of posture Facilitating the circulation of blood and lymphatic fluid Generating heat Storage of energy substrates specifically glycogen Chapter: The Anatomy of Skeletal Muscle Hi, coaches, let's move on to the topic of skeletal muscle anatomy. Understanding this is crucial for grasping how our muscles generate force, which is fundamental to HYROX performance. Picture a skeletal muscle as a complex hierarchical structure. At its core, we have rod-like structures called muscle fibers running parallel along the muscle length. These fibers aren't isolated. They are organized into progressively larger bundles, each wrapped in protective membranes. Starting from the outside, we have the epimysium, that's AP meaning upon, which encases the entire muscle. Within this, we find bundles of muscle fibers called fasciles. Each fascile has its own sheet, the limesium peri meaning around. Going even deeper within each fussicle, individual muscle fibers are separated by yet another membrane, the endomesium endo meaning inside. Now here is where it gets interesting for us as hierarch coaches. This connective tissue isn't just for protection. It extends beyond the muscle fibers converging to form tendons. These strong strap-like structures are crucial. They are what attach our muscles to our bones, specifically to the periosteum, a tough fibrous layer coating the bones. Think about the Achilles tendon or the quadricep tendon. These are prime examples of the structure and action. Understanding this anatomy helps us appreciate how force is generated and transferred during hiros movements from the wall balls to the sled push. By grasping these fundaments so we can better optimize our training strategies and help our athletes perform at their peak. Remember, every rep in hiro is this incredible in anatomical system in action. By grasping these fundamentals, we can better optimize our training strategies and help our athletes perform at their peak. Remember, every rep in HYROX is this incredible anatomical system and action. Chapter: Force generation To explain how muscles generate force it is necessary to look even closer at the fine structure of muscle fibres. Below the endomysium are even smaller rows of fibres called myofibrils. Contained within these fibres are the structures which are responsible for force production – sarcomere. Myosin and actin and the sliding filament mechanism The ‘business end’ so to speak of force generation are two contractile proteins called myosin and actin, often referred to as thick and thin filaments respectively. These are arranged in a series of compartments called sarcomeres that run the length of the myofibril. Spiraling from the myosin filament is a series of ‘hook like’ projections referred to as myosin heads. During muscular contraction these heads attach themselves to the actin filament and rotate. The result of this is that the thinner actin filaments are drawn inwards dragging the ends of the sarcomeres together, this is referred to as the sliding filament mechanism. Myosin and ATP The power to drive the myosin head is provided by adenosine triphosphate (ATP – see energy systems section). The ATP molecule primes the myosin for activity by binding with the head. Energy from the ATP is almost immediately transferred to the head rather like a finger cocking a gun. When the conditions are right, the myosin head will then bind with the actin and rotate. Actin and Calcium Although the myosin head may have been primed with energy from the ATP, it will be unable to bind with the actin without the presence of calcium. In a relaxed state, the myosin binding sites on the actin are blocked by a combination of other molecules (troponin and tropomyosin), that must be moved before myosin can be attached. Surrounding the myofibrils is a network of tubes called the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) that act as calcium reservoirs. Stimulation of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (by an action potential) causes them to release their calcium into the fluid surrounding the myosin and actin (sarcoplasm). The calcium causes the blocking molecule to move away from the myosin binding site, thus allowing the ‘primed’ myosin head to bind with the actin and rotate. Without the influx of calcium into the muscle fiber, the sliding filament mechanism could not take place. The question arises therefore, as to what triggers the sarcoplasmic reticulum to flood the myofibril with calcium. To understand this process, it is necessary to take a look at the point at which nervous impulses reach the muscle. Action Potentials The stimulus for the release of calcium is the spread of electrical activity (the action potential) along the length of the muscles. In a resting state, muscle membranes have a negatively charged interior and a positively charged exterior. The difference between the two serves as a form of potential energy, rather like that stored in a battery. This is achieved through a combination of a selective permeability of the cell membrane and the presence of sodium pumps that actively remove positively charged sodium from the cell. The arrival of an action potential at the neuromuscular junction (where the nerve meets the muscle) causes the release of a neurotransmitter (acetylcholine), which in turn causes sodium to rush through the muscle membrane. As a result, there is a reversal of electrical activity (depolarisation), which if great enough, will cascade along the muscle fiber as an action potential, thereby triggering calcium release and beginning the sliding filament mechanism. Chapter: Types of Muscle Fibre There are three different types of skeletal muscle fibres. Each different type of fibre has different characteristics. While there is variation throughout your body, there is also variation from one person to the next. This helps explain why some people are naturally good at endurance activities like running while others are naturally strong and muscular. All types of fibre respond to exercise but ultimately, limits are set by genetics – a person with lots of type 1 fibres will never be as strong as someone with lots of type 2B fibres. This is an important consideration when setting goals or selecting activities for your clients. Muscle Fiber Types Comparison Type 1 Slow twitch / Slow oxidative Structure: • Red coloured • Smallest diameter • Large myoglobin content • Many mitochondria • Many capillaries Function: • Increased aerobic delivery • Produce less force • Resistant to fatigue • Slow contractions Activities: • Maintenance of posture • Endurance based activity Type 2A Fast twitch A / Fast oxidative Structure: • Red/pink colour • Larger diameter • Large myoglobin content • Many mitochondria • Many capillaries • Fast oxidative Function: • Requires aerobic delivery • Produce more force • Less resistant to fatigue • Fast contractions Activities: • Walking • Running • Sprinting Type 2B Fast twitch B / Fast glycolytic Structure: • White/pale • Largest diameter • Small myoglobin content • Fewer mitochondria • Fewer capillaries Function: • Anaerobic delivery • Produce most force • Least resistant to fatigue • Fastest contractions Activities: • Throwing • Jumping • Weight Lifting Muscle fibre type considerations Muscles contain a mix of muscle fiber types. The activities performed will determine the proportion of each fiber type. Muscles used to support the body, such as those in the back and head, contain more type 1 fibers. In contrast, muscles responsible for the force generated by the arms and shoulders contain more type 2 fibers. The muscles in the legs have a more even distribution of both fiber types since they need to generate movement and support the body's structure. Each person has a unique combination of fiber types, which affects their athletic abilities. This explains why some people excel at endurance activities while others excel at power disciplines. Appropriate training can develop both the size and capacity of muscle fiber types. It's possible to transform one fiber type into another with a shift in training. An increase in aerobic exercise will gradually change type 2B fibers into type 2A fibers, while an increase in resistance training will have the opposite effect. Hey there, HYROX coaches. Let's have a closer look at motor units and the all or nothing law. This concept is crucial for understanding how our muscles generate force during those intense hiro workouts. Picture a muscle as a team with motor units as the individual players. Each motor unit consists of a motor neuron. Think of it as the team captain, and the muscle fibers it controls, the team members. Now, here's where it gets interesting. These motor units follow the all or nothing law. What does that mean? Well, when a stimulus is strong enough, it triggers an action potential that spreads through the entire muscle fiber. It's like when the captain gives a command and the whole team responds. But if the stimulus isn't strong enough, nothing happens. No action, no contraction. It's all or nothing, folks. So how do we control muscle force in hierarchs? It's all about recruitment and frequency. We either recruit more motor units, imagine calling in more players from the bench, or we increase how often these units fire, like asking all players to move faster. The more units we recruit and the faster they fire, the more force we generate. It's that simple. Muscle proprioceptors The muscles have two small neural sensors that provide feedback and respond to changes within the muscle. The first is the muscle spindle, located deep within the muscle fibers. The spindle is a small sensory unit wrapped around individual muscle fibers like a coiled spring. When the muscle changes length, the 'coils' of the muscle spindle are either pulled apart or pushed together, depending on whether the muscle is lengthening or shortening. This change in muscle length and the resulting change in the muscle spindle stimulate neural firing to the central nervous system at the spinal level. A lengthened muscle and muscle spindle stimulate the muscle to contract. The degree of contraction depends on the extent and rate of muscle length change. Generally, the greater the range of motion and the faster the muscle lengthens, the stronger the contraction. This process is known as the stretch reflex. The second proprioceptor, the Golgi Tendon Organ (GTO), is located in the tendon. The tendon is inelastic, so the GTO cannot detect changes in muscle length. However, when a muscle contracts, it pulls on the tendon, creating tension. The GTO measures the amount of tension and, when activated, sends a signal to the spine, causing an inhibitory effect on the same muscle. This relaxation response, due to GTO activation, is called the inverse stretch reflex. Muscle spindles are continually activated during movement as muscles change lengths with the motions performed. This provides constant information to the CNS about muscle length and body part positioning. The spindles also induce muscular contractions aiding the movements. The GTO responds after muscular contraction by inhibiting it to allow the opposite action. Thus, muscle spindles and GTOs act as on and off switches for muscle activity during exercise and movement. It's important to opposing muscles need to be switched off to allow that movement. This inhibition of opposing muscles is called Reciprocal Inhibition (RI). RI is essential for normal movement but can also contribute to muscular imbalance. A very tight muscle group can send a continuous RI signal to the opposing muscle, inhibiting its function. Exercise and training have been shown to enhance the neural side of the muscular response, improving the stretch reflex and the inverse stretch reflex. Training methods like plyometrics are designed to develop the stretch-shortening cycle effectively. This training helps muscles develop more force, and it also improves timing and coordination of movement as the muscle spindles in supporting muscle tissue respond better. Effects of exercise on muscle tissue type Exercise generally has a positive impact on muscle tissue development, but different activities influence muscle fiber types differently. Muscles have three main categories of muscle tissue: Type 1 (slow twitch), Type 2a, and Type 2b (fast twitch). Science continues to expand this knowledge, identifying other muscle tissue types based on function and response. Type 1 muscle fibers are the most aerobic, with greater blood supply and more mitochondria. They respond well to aerobic, low to moderate intensity training. Type 2b muscle fibers are very anaerobic, with reduced blood supply compared to Type 1 and fewer mitochondria. They respond well to high-intensity exercise with higher force and power outputs. Type 2a fibers have characteristics of other fast-twitch fibers but can also adapt and take on some properties of Type 1 fibers. They respond to varying levels of exercise intensity based on the applied stimulus. Muscle fatigue, soreness, and oxygen debt Muscular fatigue, a decline in the muscle's ability to produce force, is something everyone experiences. There are many stages to a muscular contraction, so the causes of muscle fatigue can vary. Fatigue may result from an interruption of any events between the CNS and the muscle fiber. Diminishing levels of neurotransmitters in the nervous system may reduce the number of action potentials reaching the muscle fibers. Complex neural interactions related to pain and discomfort perceptions may also diminish performance. Within the muscle fibers, fatigue can arise from several sources. Depletion of glycogen stores limits the rate of ATP synthesis, while insufficient oxygen leads to internal chemical changes that directly interrupt the sliding filament mechanism. The cause of fatigue depends on the mode of exercise and will be discussed in the energy systems section. Delayed Onset Muscle Soreness (DOMS) Unlike the pain or discomfort felt during exercise, delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) typically occurs 24–72 hours after a heavy exercise session. The precise mechanisms behind DOMS are still poorly understood. Some suggest the soreness relates to structural damage, while others believe it is an inflammatory response. Although the processes behind DOMS remain unclear, the causes seem to be universally agreed upon. DOMS is associated with intense eccentric muscular activity, and research also suggests that unfamiliarity with an exercise may contribute to DOMS. To minimize DOMS, there are several potential solutions. The first involves reducing eccentric muscle activity during the early stages of training, though this may be difficult to implement, especially in a sport like HYROX. The second involves starting a progressive training program at a very low intensity and gradually introducing overload. This is likely the best approach for a new client. The final approach, not for the faint-hearted, involves beginning training at a high intensity. Although DOMS will initially be high, subsequent exercise will produce less muscle soreness. Chapter: Types of Muscle Contraction Consider the bicep curl or squat and the muscles involved in these movements. Are the muscles used to lift the weight the same as those used to lower it? The answer should be ‘yes.’ However, the muscle activities are fundamentally different. When lifting the weight, the muscle shortens, and when lowering the weight, the muscle lengthens. If you pause midway, the muscle remains the same length. Throughout all these actions, the muscle is working. To distinguish between different types of muscular activity, several terms are used: Isotonic – describes muscle actions involving movement, i.e., concentric and eccentric Concentric – muscle generates force while shortening Eccentric – muscle generates force while lengthening Isometric – muscle generates force and remains the same length Isokinetic – muscle actions involving movement at a constant speed During the lifting phase of a bicep curl, the bicep brachii works concentrically. If the weight is held still at any point, this represents an isometric action. Finally, as the weight is lowered in a controlled manner, the biceps lengthen and work eccentrically. Chapter: Role of Muscle Efficient human movement relies on the coordinated activity of muscle groups, involving various combinations of different muscle actions. To understand the different roles muscles play during movement, they can be categorized as follows: Agonist/prime mover: The muscle(s) responsible for the desired action. For example, the bicep brachii during a bicep curl or the quadriceps during a leg extension. Antagonist: The opposing muscle(s) to the agonist. For instance, the triceps during a bicep curl or the hamstrings during a leg extension. Synergist: The muscle(s) that assist or modify the movement of the prime mover. For example, during hip extension, the hamstrings act as synergists for the gluteus maximus. Fixator: The muscle(s) that stabilize the part of the body that remains fixed. For instance, the shoulder girdle muscles stabilize the scapula to allow efficient movement of the shoulder joint. All right, HYROX coaches, let's wrap our heads around the next concept, muscles working in pairs. Picture this, muscles are like tag team partners positioned on opposite sides of our joints. They have opposite roles, but they work together seamlessly. Take the biceps and the triceps, for example. When you're doing those grueling wall balls, your bicep flex the elbow joint while the triceps extends it. It's a beautiful dance of contraction and relaxation known as the reciprocal inhibition. Now, here's a mind bender for you. Muscles can only pull, they can't push. Even when your athletes are grinding through push-ups or squats, what's really happening is muscles are pulling joints into extended positions or resisting gravity to control joint flexion. Every single movement in hierarchs from the sled push to the wall balls is the result of muscles pulling across joints. Understanding this concept helps you visualize the muscular action behind each hirox movement, allowing you to fine-tune your athlete's form and potentially prevent injuries. Remember, in the world of hiros and any other competitive sport, it's all about the pull. Muscle and Movement In this section, we'll present graphics showing which muscles are involved in various movements. This visual approach aims to provide a straightforward introduction to basic anatomy without too much detail. By focusing on visuals, we want to make the information accessible and easy to understand without detailed explanations. These graphics will highlight the key muscle groups activated during basic movements of different body parts, giving you a clear overview of how muscles work together. We will only show the skeleton without all the muscles, as we want to emphasize the result in movement rather than the muscles and their positioning in the body. However, for those coaches interested in a more detailed study, we will supply a list of further readings at the end of the functional anatomy module. This list will include books on anatomy where all the muscles and their positioning in the body are explained in detail. As we always say: there is no limit to what you can learn to become the best version of yourself as a HYROX coach.
