content: Titel: Level 1 - Module 5 - Vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants URL: https://web.lemon-mobile-learning.com/hyrox/#/inhalt/17887 Chapter: Vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants As an athlete, one strives for performance and optimal physical well-being. In this pursuit, minerals and vitamins play a crucial role as they fulfill essential functions in the body that are crucial for athletic performance. These nutrients not only serve for energy production but also regulate a variety of physiological processes that are essential for muscle contraction, endurance, recovery, and immunity. The knowledge about the functions of minerals and vitamins is of utmost importance for athletes. They not only support the maintenance of health and prevention of deficiencies but can also directly influence athletic performance. A targeted intake of these nutrients can contribute to optimizing metabolism, accelerating muscle regeneration, increasing resistance to injuries, and strengthening immune function. Furthermore, selecting the right foods rich in these essential nutrients can significantly contribute to enhancing your performance as an athlete. The following sections elaborate on the diverse functions of vitamins and minerals, as well as list foods abundant in these nutrients to meet your needs. In the advanced seminar, we will thoroughly discuss mineral and vitamin deficiencies, as well as the precise intake requirements for athletes and specific cases such as special needs or illnesses. Chapter: Definition vitamins Vitamins are vital components of the body that cannot be produced by the body itself. The word vitamin is made up of "vita" (Latin for "to live") and "amine", a nitrogen group that is present in some vitamins. The functions of vitamins include controlling the metabolism of proteins, participating in the formation of the body's own substances such as enzymes, hormones, bones, blood cells etc., supporting the immune system and controlling numerous biochemical reactions. Vitamins can be divided into fat-soluble (lipophilic) and water-soluble (hydrophilic) based on their solubility. Fat-soluble vitamins require fat as a means of transportation and can be stored in the body, which in very rare cases can lead to an overdose. Water-soluble vitamins can dissolve in water and are therefore not stored in large quantities in the body. Excess amounts are excreted in the urine, so a daily intake is necessary. Chapter: Fat-soluble vitamins Vitamin A The fat-soluble vitamin A occurs in the form of retinol and is mainly found in animal sources such as liver, egg yolk, fish and milk. It also includes provitamin A carotenoids such as beta-carotene, which are mainly found in green vegetables and carrots. Vitamin A is crucial for various aspects of human health and development. The most important functions are to support embryonic development, body growth, visual function, spermatogenesis and the immune system by increasing the activity of defense cells and improving the immune response to infections. Vitamin D Vitamin D, also known as the sunshine vitamin, exists in several forms, with the two most important being Vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol) and Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol). Vitamin D3 can be obtained both from food sources and synthesized by the body in the skin upon exposure to sunlight. Particularly good sources include cod liver oil and fatty fish. Vitamin D supports the immune system, reduces inflammation, and is crucial for bone health primarily through its role in regulating calcium and phosphate levels and promoting bone mineralization and hardening. Vitamin E Vitamin E refers to a group of fat-soluble vitamins sharing a similar chemical structure and is an important antioxidant in the body. The most well-known forms are tocopherols and tocotrienols. It is found primarily in high-quality plant oils such as rapeseed oil and in nuts like almonds and hazelnuts. Its key functions include anti-inflammatory properties by attenuating inflammatory responses, protection against cell damage, and acting as an antioxidant by scavenging free radicals. Vitamin K Vitamin K is divided into two main forms: phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) and menaquinone (Vitamin K2), both of which are significant for nutrition. These two forms are primarily found in green vegetables such as broccoli, spinach, and kale, fermented products, and poultry and beef. Its key functions include acting as blood clotting factors to stop bleeding and regulating calcium metabolism and bone mineralization. Vitamins Overview Vitamin A Function: Embryonic development, body growth, vision function, spermatogenesis, immune system Food Sources: Liver, egg yolk, fish, and milk, green vegetables, carrots Requirements: Men: 1.0–1.1 mg/day | Women: 0.8–1.0 mg/day Vitamin D Function: Immune system, bones, nerves Food Sources: Cod liver oil, fatty fish Requirements: 20 µg/day Vitamin E Function: Anti-inflammatory, protection against cell damage, antioxidant effect Food Sources: Rapeseed oil, nuts, grains Requirements: Men: 12–15 mg/day | Women: 11–12 mg/day Vitamin K Function: Blood clotting, calcium metabolism Food Sources: Broccoli, spinach, kale, fermented products, chicken, beef Requirements: Men: 70–80 µg/day | Women: 60–65 µg/day Chapter: Water-soluble vitamins Vitamin C - Ascorbic acid Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid: Humans rely on external sources of Vitamin C. It is found in both animal and plant sources, with plant sources containing significantly higher concentrations. Citrus fruits, berries, kiwis, and various vegetables such as broccoli, bell peppers, and green leafy vegetables contain high amounts of Vitamin C. Its key functions include protection against free radicals, strengthening the immune system, participation in collagen formation, and enhancing iron absorption. Vitamin B1 - Thiamine Thiamine is a molecule of Vitamin B1 and is typically found in low concentrations in the diet. It is primarily present in whole grains, nuts and seeds, legumes, meat, and dairy products. Its key functions include supporting the conversion of carbohydrates into energy, participating in the synthesis of neurotransmitters, and acting as a cofactor in energy metabolism for heart and muscle function. Vitamin B2 - Riboflavin Vitamin B2 is also referred to as the "growth vitamin" and primarily supports growth and development. It contributes to the health of skin, hair, and nails, participates in the formation of antioxidants, and supports energy production. It is found in higher concentrations in dairy products, meat, fish, eggs, and in relatively lower concentrations in grains, vegetables, and fruits. Vitamin B3 - Niacin Vitamin B3 is involved in DNA repair and cell regulation, supports skin health by strengthening the skin barrier, contributes to improving cholesterol levels, and is involved as NAD in the citric acid cycle, fatty acid oxidation, and in the respiratory chain. It is found in food sources such as whole grain products, yeast products, nuts, vegetables, as well as meat, fish, and dairy products. Vitamin B5 - Pantothenic acid Pantothenic acid is almost always present in its active form, coenzyme A. It is important for skin elasticity and regeneration, plays a role in cell division and growth, and is essential for the synthesis of fatty acids through its involvement in the citric acid cycle and fatty acid oxidation. It is found in foods such as meat, egg yolks, fish, as well as legumes, and grains. Vitamin B6 Vitamin B6 exists in various forms such as pyridoxine, pyridoxal, and pyridoxamine and is converted into its active form in the body. Its key functions include the regulation of numerous metabolic reactions, the biosynthesis of neurotransmitters, and participation in the formation of hemoglobin. Foods rich in Vitamin B6 include meat, fish, (sweet) potatoes, avocados, nuts, and legumes. Vitamin B7 - Biotin Biotin is involved in the energy metabolism by supporting the conversion of nutrients into energy. Biotin is considered a key enzyme in gluconeogenesis for the regulation of blood sugar levels. It also plays an important role in healthy skin by aiding in the formation of fatty acids, is important for cell growth and tissue repair, and is involved in the creatine metabolism, which is important for healthy hair and nails. Biotin-rich foods include eggs, dairy products, meat, fish, legumes, and vegetables such as spinach and broccoli. Folate - Folic acid Folate is present in many different substances. Its functions include the production of new cells and repair of DNA damage, as well as involvement in embryonic neural tube closure, which is why folic acid is particularly important during pregnancy. High concentrations are found in wheat germ, egg yolks, leafy vegetables, yeast, and whole grain products. Vitamin B12 Vitamin B12 also known as cobalamin, is found only in animal-derived foods such as fish, meat, eggs, and dairy products. Fermented products like sauerkraut may contain small traces of the vitamin, but they are not sufficient to meet the body's needs. Important functions of vitamin B12 include the synthesis of red blood cells, the formation and regeneration of nerve cells, and many other crucial bodily processes. Those most at risk for deficiency are individuals following a vegan diet who do not supplement their intake with supplements. Vitamin B1 – Thiamine Function: Neurotransmitters, energy metabolism Food Sources: Whole grains, nuts, seeds, legumes, meat, dairy products Requirements: Men: 1.1–1.4 mg/day | Women: 1.0–1.1 mg/day Vitamin B2 – Riboflavin Function: Growth, development, energy metabolism Food Sources: Dairy products, meat, fish, eggs Requirements: Men: 1.2–1.5 mg/day | Women: 1.2 mg/day Niacin Function: Repair mechanisms, energy metabolism Food Sources: Whole grains, yeast, nuts, vegetables, meat, fish, dairy products Requirements: Men: 13–17 mg/day | Women: 13 mg/day Pantothenic acid Function: Immune system, nerves, cell growth Food Sources: Meat, egg yolks, fish, legumes, grains Requirements: 6 mg/day Vitamin B6 Function: Metabolism, neurotransmitters Food Sources: Meat, fish, (sweet) potatoes, avocados, nuts, legumes Requirements: Men: 1.4 mg/day | Women: 1.5–1.6 mg/day Biotin Function: Skin, hair, nails, energy metabolism Food Sources: Eggs, dairy products, meat, fish, legumes, vegetables Requirements: 30–60 µg/day Folate Function: Growth, regeneration mechanisms Food Sources: Wheat germ, egg yolks, leafy greens, yeast, whole grains Requirements: 300 µg/day Vitamin B12 Function: Nerves, red blood cells Food Sources: Fish, meat, eggs, and dairy products Requirements: 4.0 µg/day Vitamin C Function: Immune system, antioxidant effect Food Sources: Citrus fruits, berries, kiwis, broccoli, bell peppers, green leafy vegetables Requirements: 100 mg/day Chapter: Minerals Minerals Minerals are essential nutrients that are absorbed through our diet and are divided into two main categories: macrominerals and trace minerals. Macrominerals are those that occur in quantities of at least 50 mg per kilogram of body weight, while trace minerals are present in smaller amounts, less than 50 mg per kilogram of body weight (with the exception of iron, which is around 60 mg/kg BW but is still considered a trace mineral). The variety of tasks that minerals fulfill in the body is enormous and varies greatly from one mineral to another. Therefore, this module focuses specifically on shedding light on the most important macrominerals and trace minerals in detail to provide a comprehensive understanding of their significance for human health. Important macrominerals: Magnesium Magnesium is one of the most important minerals and is involved in all ATP-dependent processes (energy metabolism processes). It plays a decisive role in the regulation of nerve and muscle activity as well as the mineralization of bones and teeth. Wholemeal products, oatmeal, bananas, meat and fish are good sources of magnesium. A magnesium-rich mineral water is recommended. Potassium Potassium is the most important intracellular electrolyte and the antagonist of sodium. It also contributes to the regulation of the water balance, stimulus transmission and contraction and helps to build up ATP and store glycogen in the muscles. Potassium-rich foods are vegetables and fruit as well as potatoes and wholegrain products. Sodium Sodium acts as a counterpart to potassium in the body and plays a crucial role in regulating blood pressure and fluid balance by significantly influencing the pressure in the cells. Sodium is important for nerve and muscle conduction. Around 100 g of sodium is present in the human body and is mainly found in body fluids. Sodium can be easily absorbed through sports drinks. Calcium Calcium is found almost exclusively in our extracellular skeletal system and in our teeth and has a decisive influence on bone health. Calcium also plays a key role in various important processes in the body, for example in blood clotting and the initiation of muscle contraction, as well as in the regulation of nerve transmission. Calcium-rich products include kale, broccoli and various nuts. Important trace minerals: Iron Iron in the human body is divided into two forms: Functional iron and storage iron. Functional iron is actively involved in biological processes and is present in compounds that fulfill a specific biological function. For example, iron is a component of hemoglobin and myoglobin, where it binds oxygen and enables the transport and storage of oxygen. Storage iron serves as a reserve and is present in biologically inactive compounds. The largest iron reserves are found in the form of ferritin in the bone marrow, liver and spleen and there is a total of approx. 3-5g in the body. Iron-rich products are red meat, liver, oysters, soy flour and millet. Zinc Zinc, the second most abundant trace mineral in the body, plays a crucial role in numerous processes important for health. It supports the immune system, promotes the health of skin, hair, and nails, and serves as a cofactor for many biochemical processes in the body, including testosterone formation. Good sources of zinc include liver, oysters, eggs, and dairy products. Selenium Selenium is an essential trace mineral that plays a significant role in thyroid health by supporting and regulating its function. Additionally, it acts as a potent antioxidant, providing cellular protection, promoting detoxification in the body, and strengthening the immune system. Excellent sources of selenium include meat, fish, and various types of nuts. Copper Copper is an important trace mineral in the human body and plays a crucial role in various physiological processes. It is essential for iron metabolism and serves as a cofactor in the conversion of stored iron to transport iron. Additionally, it supports the function of antioxidants, promotes collagen synthesis for healthy skin and tissues, and is involved in regulating energy metabolism. Good dietary sources of copper include liver, fish, and shellfish. Iodine Iodine is mainly found in fish and iodized salt and plays a crucial role in regulating thyroid function. It is essential for the production of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which regulate metabolism, thermoregulation, and many other vital processes in the body. Additionally, it is involved in controlling protein, carbohydrate, and fat metabolism. Chapter: Antioxidants A variety of vitamins also act as antioxidants. These chemical compounds have the ability to protect the body from free radicals, which can damage the body. Free radicals, among the most aggressive molecules in the body, are generated as natural byproducts of cellular metabolism or enter the body through exposure to environmental toxins such as cigarette smoke or alcohol. Their aggressive nature stems from their chemical structure, which results in an unpaired electron in their outermost shell. To maintain their own stability, free radicals seek to destabilize other molecules by stealing an electron from them. Antioxidants function by either donating an electron to free radicals or accepting an unpaired electron, thereby becoming radicals themselves. This process neutralizes the free radicals and halts their harmful effects before they can trigger a chain reaction. Examples of antioxidants include vitamins A, B2, C, E, as well as minerals like zinc, iron, selenium, and secondary plant compounds.

Chapter: Digestion of proteins We usually consume amino acids in the form of proteins in our diet. Our food choices provide us with the amino acids we need. In order to make these usable for the human organism, the proteins are first digested, the peptide compounds are broken down and the individual amino acids become usable for the organism. The metabolism of proteins begins in the stomach, where the large pieces of protein are broken down by pepsins. Further splitting into smaller pieces is carried out by peptidases (e.g. trypsin from the pancreas in the small intestine). The proteins are broken down into di- and tripeptides and amino acids. The amino acids are absorbed directly into the portal vein via the intestinal wall (small intestinal mucosa), whereas the di- and tripeptides are broken down into amino acids in the cytoplasm before they enter the bloodstream. Whenever proteins are broken down, more heat is released. This is also known as thermogenesis. This means that when proteins are digested, 30% of the energy absorbed is converted into heat and is therefore not available for further energy metabolism. This is one of the reasons why proteins and amino acids are not ideal as energy sources during exercise. Chapter: Biological value of proteins The biological value of proteins is used to assess protein quality and is defined as follows: The number of grams of body protein that can be replaced by 100 g of the dietary protein in question. This means that a protein with a high biological value can be converted to a high proportion of the body's own protein. Chicken whole egg is the reference value here with a value of 100. Biological value of proteins: Chicken whole egg: 100 Potatoes: 86 Pork: 85 Edam cheese: 85 Milk: 84 Soy: 84 Swiss cheese: 83 Tuna: 83 Beef: 83 Rye: 83 Rice: 83 Corn: 76 Beans: 72 Wheat: 58 In addition to the value of individual foods, the optimization of the value by combining different foods should be considered. This is because the combination of different protein sources in particular can increase the usability and thus the biological value. And in some cases this can be well above the value of 100: 36% whole egg + 64% potatoes: 136 60% whole egg + 40% soy: 124 86% whole egg + 32% wheat: 118 36% whole egg + 64% beans: 108 75% milk + 25% wheat: 106 56% milk + 44% rye: 101 52% beans + 48% corn: 99 50% milk + 50% potatoes: 92 77% beef + 23% potatoes: 90 Chapter: Daily protein intake and requirements The recommendation for protein intake in Germany is 0.8g / kgKG for adults under 65 years of age. Due to the high influence of proteins on training adaptation, a protein intake of 1.2-2.0g / kgKG is recommended internationally for athletes. Especially in phases of a new training cycle or for less trained athletes, this requirement may be even higher. The following general recommendations can be made Regular endurance training: 1.2-1.4g / kgKG / d Regular strength training: 1.7-1.8g / kgKG / d Strength athletes: 2.0g / kgKG / d The amino acid requirement results primarily from the need for essential amino acids. The daily intake recommendations for adults range from 4-5 mg per kilogram (kg) of body weight (kg) for tryptophan to 39-42 mg/kg bw for leucine. On days with intensive training, increased food intake with a high protein content should not only accelerate regeneration, but also achieve muscle growth in particular. A surplus of energy is generally necessary for this. This excess energy results in an anabolic metabolic state via the release of mTOR - a growth factor. Proteins, together with a high proportion of carbohydrates, support this signaling pathway. The growth factor mTOR is the antagonist of AMPK (see carbohydrate metabolism). AMPK is released in the so-called catabolic state - starvation metabolism - of a cell. In principle, HYROX athletes should also aim to alternate between the two cell states in order to provide the best possible training stimuli. See also the chapter on special diets such as intermittent fasting. Protein-rich foods are primarily animal products, which also have a very high biological value. However, plant-based foods can also have a high protein content and can have an equally high or even improved biological value when combined with other foods. This list provides an overview of the protein content of various foods. The list does not claim to be exhaustive of all available foods, but is intended to provide a good overview: Chapter: Essential and non-essential amino acids 20 proteinogenic amino acids are used to build proteins, some of which are considered some of which are considered "essential amino acids". These cannot be synthesized by the body itself and must therefore be supplied through food. A distinction is therefore made between essential and non-essential amino acids. The non-essential amino acids can be produced by the human organism itself. This means that the body can assemble them from other proteins or amino acids and thus make them usable. Essential amino acids, on the other hand, cannot be produced by the body itself. These amino acids must be supplied through the diet according to current requirements. There are also semi-essential amino acids. The body can form these itself, but this synthesis only takes place to a limited extent and the demand in the organism is often higher than the rate of formation in the body. For this reason, the semi-essential amino acids must also be supplied in sufficient quantities via the diet. Valine Valine provides energy for the muscle cells and sends important messenger substances for the nervous system. Contained in: Chlorella, spirulina, peas, chicken, whole wheat flour, cheese Leucine Leucine is involved in the formation and maintenance of muscle protein, provides muscles with energy and supports healing processes. Contained in: Chicken breast, peas, salmon, egg, walnuts, whole wheat flour Isoleucine Isoleucine is involved in the maintenance and regeneration of muscle tissue. It is also an important source of energy. Contained in: Chicken breast, peas, salmon, egg, walnuts, whole wheat flour Phenylalanine Phenylalanine is involved in the formation of numerous proteins and important hormones such as adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine. Contained in: Soybeans, pumpkin seeds, peas, poultry, walnuts, pork, salmon, egg Threonine Task: involved in the provision of vitamin B12. Contained in: Chicken breast filet, beef, peas, salmon, walnuts, egg, whole wheat flour Methionine Methionine supports the formation of proteins and fat metabolism. Contained in: Brazil nuts, salmon, sesame seeds, beef, egg, broccoli, peas, spinach, corn, millet Lysine Lysine supports the maintenance of connective and muscle tissue. It is also involved in fat metabolism. Contained in: Pumpkin seeds, chicken breast, salmon, peas, tofu, egg, buckwheat flour, walnuts Tryptophan Tryptophan can influence mood as a precursor of serotonin, known as the "feel-good hormone". Contained in: Soybeans, cocoa powder (unsweetened), cashews, peas, chicken breast Histidine Histidine is important for gluconeogenesis. The breakdown products of this glucogenic amino acid are used for the reconstruction of gluten. The carbon skeleton of histidine enters the citrate cycle via α-ketoglutarate, whose immediate precursor is glutamic acid. Contained in: Beef, chicken breast, salmon, chicken egg, cow's milk, walnuts, wheat flour, corn flour, rice, soybeans, peas. Chapter: Functions of amino acids in the human body This section is intended to provide an overview of the function of selected amino acids in the human body. In particular, we will look at the amino acids that have a significant influence on muscle metabolism during exercise, as well as those amino acids that particularly support muscle regeneration. We will also take a closer look at amino acids that can have a universally positive influence on regeneration, especially sleep, or whose deficiency can have a negative effect on recovery. As mentioned at the beginning, amino acids have different functions in the human body. Some amino acids are precursors of neurotransmitters or hormones. This therefore also means that a lack of certain amino acids can lead to a lack of neurotransmitters and hormones in the body. In the context of HYROX, the amino acids are certainly the first to receive decisive attention, as they support the repair function of the muscles and thus also the development of muscles. However, in addition to this function, the amino acids should also be considered in terms of their function for the other organs of the human organism. Only the interaction and optimal function of all organ systems in the body enable optimal performance. This applies to both training and competition. We should pay particular attention to training or, even better, the time between individual training sessions. Well-structured and optimally organized training is most successful if we also take into account the time between the individual units in hours or days when planning. The body's adaptation processes take place during the regeneration period. Our choice of food can either improve or worsen the recovery time. We should therefore choose our food carefully. Chapter: Regeneration and sleep A good night's sleep is the absolute prerequisite for an adequate effect of a training stimulus. Without restful sleep, optimal adaptation to training cannot take place. The semi-essential amino acid L-tyrosine is needed to synthesize noradrenaline and adrenaline. However, L-tyrosine is also necessary for the adequate function of the thyroid gland. Without L-tyrosine, thyroid hormones cannot be produced. L-tyrosine is produced from phenylalanine in the liver. However, if the liver is not functioning adequately, e.g. due to an excessive consumption of sugar (be careful with too much fructose over 50g/day) or alcohol, then the formation in the liver is not sufficient for the supply and L-tyrosine is no longer semi-essential, but essential for the organism. Fructose in particular, as a component of numerous industrial foods and sports foods, quickly poses the risk of liver overload and also intestinal overload. As the thyroid gland is the "rest manager" in the body and plays an important key role in the body's ability to regenerate as well as in energy distribution, this example is intended to emphasize the enormous importance of L-tyrosine as well as the optimal function of the liver and thyroid gland for athletic performance. L-tryptophan is an equally important essential amino acid for the regeneration period. The main reason for this is that L-tryptophan is the precursor of the happiness hormone serotonin. An optimal serotonin level is in turn crucial for maintaining the balance of cortisol and melatonin. Cortisol is our stress hormone, which keeps us awake and is mainly released during the day. Melatonin, on the other hand, is its antagonist and is our sleep hormone. For a good and regenerative sleep, we need a sufficient level of melatonin. L-tryptophan plays a key role here and should be consumed in sufficient quantities each day. The daily intake recommendations for adults range from 4-5 mg per kilogram (kg) of body weight (kg). Chapter: Important amino acids for muscle building and muscle maintenance Skeletal muscle consists of 35% BCAAs and almost 60% glutamine. The amino acids that are particularly important for muscle regeneration are the non-essential amino acid L-glutamine and the three consumable essential amino acids valine, leucine and isoleucine. Also known as BCAAs = Branched-Chain Amino Acids. BCAAs are important during intensive training, as they prevent the body's own muscle mass from being used for energy and thus prevent muscle breakdown. They also ensure more effective muscle building after training and at the same time promote fat loss. Among other things, BCAAs are involved in muscle building, metabolism, wound healing and tissue formation. A deficiency of individual amino acids in the BCAA complex can lead to fatigue and an increased incidence of colds. BCAAs cannot be synthesized in the body, they are only taken in with food. Valine, leucine and isoleucine are the only amino acids that are not metabolized in the liver, but directly in the muscles. This explains their importance in sport, as they increase the energy production of the muscles. BCAAs also fulfill the following functions: *counteract increased protein breakdown; are therefore used as an accompanying therapy for tumor diseases *are used for liver diseases *promote the maintenance and development of muscle tissue *regulate the body's energy supply *are a component of glucose production *stimulate the release of insulin and regulate blood sugar levels *maintain the body's nitrogen balance *contribute to healthy growth in children and adolescents Recommended daily intake The following daily intake of BCAA is recommended for healthy adults (in milligrams per kilogram of body weight): Leucine: 42mg Isoleucine: 19mg Valine: 24mg Sample calculation According to the above intake recommendations, an adult weighing 70 kg needs 2.9 g leucine, 1.3 g isoleucine and 1.7 g valine per day. These three amino acids can either be supplemented individually or in the form of a complete protein such as whey. That makes 5.9g BCAA per day. 3 of 12 Higher requirement for athletes Athletes in training sometimes have a higher requirement and should therefore supplement with 10 to 20g of BCAA per day. If athletes train a lot and do not consume enough amino acids through food or supplements, this can lead to a BCAA deficiency. Anyone who does not get a sufficient amount of protein in their daily diet should consider supplementing with BCAAs. Possible risk groups for deficiency BCAA deficiencies are relatively rare, but do occur in some cases in athletes. People who suffer from a vitamin deficiency (vitamin B5 and vitamin B6) or a glutamine deficiency (see also the topic of the gut) are also at risk. Vitamin deficiency A lack of vitamins B5 and B6 can also promote a BCAA deficiency, especially a valine deficiency. These two vitamins are also needed to supply the muscles with energy. If they are not available in sufficient quantities, the amino acids attempt to replace the deficiency. The result is an increased need for BCAA. More on vitamins in the corresponding chapter. Glutamine deficiency A glutamine deficiency, which can occur in the case of intestinal infections or stress, for example, can also lead to a BCAA deficiency. As a non-essential amino acid, glutamine is actually produced by the body itself. However, if the body's own synthesis is limited, it can also be produced from the amino acid BCAA as an alternative. This increased BCAA consumption can lead to a deficiency if the stores are not replenished. A good test for a glutamine deficiency is an intestinal test for the so-called leaky gut. The permeable intestine. In this case, glutamine deficiency leads to increased intestinal permeability. Symptoms can include chronic tiredness, fatigue and susceptibility to infections. Foods with BCCA The branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine and isoleucine are mainly found in protein-rich foods. BCAAs make up around half of the amino acids in food, so getting enough is rarely a problem. Plant-based foods with BCAA (Data per 100g of food) Wheat products: 0.9g leucine Peanuts: 1.2g isoleucine; 1.5g valine; 2g leucine Rice, unpolished: 0.3g isoleucine; 0.5g valine; 0.7g leucine Peas, dried: 1.2g valine and isoleucine each Walnuts: 0.8g each of valine and isoleucine Animal foods (Data per 100g of food) Beef fillet: 1.2g isoleucine; 1.3g valine; 2.0g leucine Tuna: 1.2g isoleucine; 1.4g valine; 2.2g leucine Milk: 0.2g isoleucine; 0.2g valine; 0.4g leucine Salmon, raw: 1.6g leucine Substances that promote BCAA absorption The three amino acids valine, leucine and isoleucine can be metabolized particularly well if the body also has sufficient vitamin B5 available. In combination with this vitamin, which is also used to generate energy in the muscles, BCAAs develop their full effect. However, if vitamin B5 is lacking, BCAA synthesis can also be severely impaired. Possible secondary diseases in case of deficiency A BCAA deficiency is extremely rare. However, if it does occur, it can lead to the following diseases and damage: Disorders in insulin production Changes in the blood sugar level Deterioration of the immune system High blood pressure Mood swings exhaustion Dysfunction of the liver neurological disorders Treating BCAA deficiency If you have been diagnosed with an actual BCAA deficiency, this can easily be remedied by eating a balanced diet. Beef, fresh salmon, wheat products, rice and many other protein sources contain plenty of BCAA. Athletes who have a higher nutrient requirement can supplement BCAAs with a complete protein. Whey protein (whey) has a particularly high BCAA content. The normal dosage for BCAAs is around five to ten grams per day, although athletes often take double this dose. Beware of overdosing Excessive doses of BCAA prevent other amino acids from crossing the blood-brain barrier and being synthesized into neurotransmitters in the brain. As a result, the body has too little serotonin available, for example, which in the worst case can lead to depressive moods and migraines. People who suffer from depression and other illnesses with low serotonin levels should avoid an increased intake of BCAAs. Preventing BCAA deficiency A balanced diet with sufficient protein, fish, meat and vegetables is sufficient to provide the body with an optimal supply of BCAAs. Vegetarians can prevent with plant-based suppliers Vegetarians also have plenty of foods that provide BCAA, such as peas, rice, wheat products and peanuts. During intensive training phases, it can also be useful to take a high-quality complete protein with a high BCAA content for an optimal BCAA supply. Chapter: Glutamine One of the essential amino acids is called glutamine and is significantly involved in building and maintaining muscle mass in our body. Glutamine is also the main source of energy for our intestinal cells. A lack of glutamine can also promote a lack of the BCAAs described above. A sufficient supply of glutamine should therefore be ensured, especially during intensive sport such as HYROX. Glutamine performs these tasks Glutamine is required for various processes in the body. The most important of these are: Glutamine is one of the most important nutrients for the cells of the immune system. It also promotes the formation of white blood cells, which specifically fight pathogens. Glutamine is also the most important source of energy for the digestive system. It provides nutrition for the cells of the small intestine and maintains intestinal function and structure. In the event of stress caused by surgical interventions or toxins, this ensures rapid regeneration of the intestinal surface. Glutamine also helps to speed up recovery from intestinal inflammation. Glutamine is significantly involved in muscle mass. It is the most important amino acid for muscles. It is particularly important for athletes. Furthermore, glutamine stimulates the release of growth hormones and thus supports the regeneration of the body (especially during sleep). Glutamine is also needed to build up messenger substances in the brain. Glutamine is also involved in the regulation of the acid-base balance. Excess acids can be bound in the body and excreted. Glutamine has an antioxidant effect, which protects the cells in the body The intestine requires the largest proportion of glutamine in the body, as it serves as the main source of energy for the cells of the intestinal mucosa. These have numerous important functions, including digestion and immune defense. Studies show that glutamine mainly helps with illnesses or damage to the intestinal mucosa. As a protein building block, it promotes protein production in the intestinal cells so that regeneration processes can take place quickly. In this case, between 5,000 and 25,000 mg of glutamine is recommended daily. Glutamine can also contribute to a rapid improvement in intestinal diseases such as leaky gut syndrome or Crohn's disease. For these conditions, 5,000 to 15,000 mg of glutamine per day is recommended. Additional glutamine is recommended for athletes. Although it does not promote muscle growth in healthy athletes, it does support muscle regeneration after exercise. With 4,000 to 20,000 mg of glutamine daily, athletes could: *reduce muscle soreness, *support the immune system during extreme physical exertion, *reduce the ammonia content in the blood, which leads to fatigue after exercise and *in combination with carbohydrates, improve the replenishment of their energy reserves Too little glutamine - these can be the consequences People with chronic and/or serious illnesses in particular often have a glutamine deficiency. This can be triggered by the following: *Chronic inflammatory diseases in the gastrointestinal tract *Liver damage *Heavy alcohol consumption *Extraordinary strain, high stress *Amino acid deficiency due to genetic diseases Further signs are: *Brittle nails *Dull hair and hair loss *Imbalance, sleep disorders and restlessness *Reduced physical and mental performance, lack of concentration and even confusion *Dwindling muscle mass *urine smelling of ammonia *Fluctuating pH value in the blood *Increased susceptibility to infections *inflammation of the mucous membranes *Wound healing disorder Other risk groups for a glutamine deficiency are patients with traumatic brain injury, chronic inflammatory bowel disease, severe burns, short bowel syndrome and people with blood poisoning, HIV disease and those undergoing chemotherapy. For example, glutamine is found in foods per 100 g (mg/100g): *Cheese: 3050-8100 *Peanuts: 5630 *Spelt flour: 5170 *Mung bean: 4810 *Soybean: 6490 *Lentils: 4490 *Mutton: 4300 *Beef: 4130 *Wheat: 4080 *Pork: 3910 *Chicken: 3500

Chapter: Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids Polyunsaturated fatty acids are categorized into Omega-9, Omega-6, and Omega-3 fatty acids. A physiological advantage of polyunsaturated fatty acids over saturated fatty acids can be easily remembered by considering their respective melting points. Saturated fatty acids, like those in butter or milk, are very hard and have a high melting point, above our average body core temperature of 36 degrees Celsius. Omega-9 fatty acids, found in olive oil, have a melting point of just 10 degrees Celsius. Omega-6 fatty acids, such as those in flaxseed oil, melt at 0-4 degrees Celsius. Omega-3 fatty acids from fish are even more fluid. Imagine the incorporation of different fatty acids into the cell membranes in our tissues. The organism requires an adequate amount of polyunsaturated fatty acids for elastic blood vessels. Excessive consumption of dairy products and meat from factory farming leads to a decrease in the elasticity of blood vessels and ultimately brings further negative health consequences such as promoting the development of diabetes or increasing the risk of heart attacks in the long term. Omega-6 fatty acids, except for alpha-linolenic acid, primarily act as pro-inflammatory in the body. This isn't always necessarily bad. However, it is important to pay attention to the ratio of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids in the blood. Ideally, this ratio should be no more than 1:4. Chapter: What does the Omega-3 Index describe? A physiological advantage of polyunsaturated fatty acids over saturated fatty acids can be easily remembered by considering their respective melting points. Saturated fatty acids, like those in butter or milk, are very hard and have a high melting point, above our average body core temperature of 36 degrees Celsius. Omega-9 fatty acids, found in olive oil, have a melting point of just 10 degrees Celsius. Omega-6 fatty acids, such as those in flaxseed oil, melt at 0-4 degrees Celsius. Omega-3 fatty acids from fish are even more fluid. Imagine the incorporation of different fatty acids into the cell membranes in our tissues. The organism requires an adequate amount of polyunsaturated fatty acids for elastic blood vessels. Excessive consumption of dairy products and meat from factory farming leads to a decrease in the elasticity of blood vessels and ultimately brings further negative health consequences such as promoting the development of diabetes or increasing the risk of heart attacks in the long term. Omega-6 fatty acids, except for alpha-linolenic acid, primarily act as pro-inflammatory in the body. This isn't always necessarily bad. However, it is important to pay attention to the ratio of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids in the blood. Ideally, this ratio should be no more than 1:4. The Omega-3 Index can be determined through a blood test. It measures the proportion of polyunsaturated omega-3 fatty acids, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in the membrane of red blood cells. It reflects the body's omega-3 status over the past 4 months, similar to how hemoglobin A1C indicates long-term blood sugar levels. An Omega-3 Index in the range of 8–12% is considered optimal for maintaining the health of the brain, heart, and metabolism. As important players in the immune system, EPA and DHA regulate inflammatory processes; they have anti-inflammatory effects and help calm the immune system after a defensive reaction. During an immune reaction, pro-inflammatory substances increase first, including the release of arachidonic acid from cell membranes – an omega-6 fatty acid. This is necessary for the immune reaction to properly begin. This reaction can also occur conditionally after a tough and intense training session. All of our cells are surrounded by membranes – delicate shells made of phospholipids that separate the cell from the environment and selectively allow substances to pass through. What we eat significantly determines the properties and function of these membranes. Therefore, we have control over whether they are fluid, flexible, and functional, or rigid and limited in their work. Omega-3 fatty acids are also components of these membranes and are largely responsible for their flexibility. During an immune reaction – as well as after a tough training session or competition – these fatty acids are released from the cell membranes to unleash their immune-modulating properties. Receptor functions, such as the signal transmission of insulin and thus the uptake of glucose into the cell, also depend on a flexible membrane. The insulin sensitivity of our cells is crucial for a well-functioning metabolism. See the chapter on carbohydrates for more information. Chapter: Omega 6: Omega 3 – The Ratio Matters Critical for this delicate interplay of inflammation and healing is not only the amount of Omega-3 but also its ratio to the polyunsaturated Omega-6 fatty acid, arachidonic acid, which should ideally be at a maximum of 1:4. However, in Western industrialized nations, due to high consumption of meat, processed meats, and dairy products from factory farming, ratios of 1:25 or higher are not uncommon. When cell membranes are not adequately supplied with Omega-3, immune reactions are neither kept in check nor timely terminated. This increases the risk of chronic low-grade inflammation, which can, over time, drain energy and diminish training and competition performance. Chronic inflammation can be sustained for years due to lifestyle factors such as stress, unhealthy diet, nutrient deficiencies (Omega-3!), or lack of exercise, but especially due to overtraining (!). Similar to the embers of a fire, this inflammation smolders, producing harmful smoke and consuming vast amounts of energy. The responsiveness of the immune system becomes more rigid, the immune response stronger and less controlled. Energy for athletic performance becomes increasingly scarce. Chapter: Nutrition as Medicine It should be clear that it is important not only to supply Omega-3 in case of illness. The fatty acids must already be incorporated into the cell membranes beforehand to unleash their anti-inflammatory effects. EPA and DHA are essential fatty acids that our bodies cannot produce on their own. We must obtain them through diet. They can be found in fish, seafood, algae, and in smaller doses in wild game and animals raised on pasture. There are occasional claims that flaxseed oil or walnuts are rich in Omega-3 fats. However, these contain only the precursor to EPA and DHA, alpha-linolenic acid. Its conversion rate to the desired fatty acids is at most 5%, often only 2-3% in our regions. Unfortunately, this is insufficient for a good amount of EPA and DHA. Consuming fish, seafood, or algae at least three times a week provides a good foundation for supplying essential Omega-3 fatty acids and has a positive impact on regeneration. It's crucial to pay attention to the quality and type, as fish, especially large species like tuna, are heavily contaminated with heavy metals. The WWF fish guide can assist you in making choices. In case of a deficiency (e.g., due to existing chronic illnesses, unbalanced diet, stress, etc.), supplementation with purified fish or algae oil as a supplement is often recommended to restore the level to an optimal value. A healthy distribution of fatty acids is found in the following foods: *Rapeseed oil *Flaxseed oil *Hemp oil *Walnut oil *Omega-3 margarine *Nuts and seeds *Seafood (herring, salmon, tuna) *Olives and olive oil *Avocado Fats that should be avoided due to their fatty acid distribution: *Safflower oil *Sunflower oil *Vegetable margarine *Corn oil *Soybean oil Short-chain fatty acids (SCFA), including acetate, propionate, and butyrate, are metabolites of the gut microbiome that have important functions in the human body. Not only does the integrity of the intestinal epithelium depend on an adequate supply of SCFA, but systemic processes such as glucose metabolism and the regulation of appetite and satiety are also influenced by SCFA. Their determination in stool and serum can therefore identify new curative and preventive approaches. SCFA are produced by gut bacteria. Short-chain fatty acids are formed in the colon during the fermentation of non-absorbed carbohydrates, such as dietary fiber, complex carbohydrates, or resistant starch. The composition of the microbiome in the gut is crucial for optimal SCFA formation. The SCFA-producing bacterial genera in the microbiome are particularly important. By supplying fermentable fibers, these bacteria can be selectively increased, and their metabolic activity enhanced.

Chapter: Digestion of carbohydrates If carbohydrate sources are ingested with food, carbohydrate metabolism begins in the mouth. The enzyme amylase begins to break down the macromolecules in the oral cavity and is continued in the small intestine (small intestinal mucosa) by the digestive enzyme alpha-amylase from the pancreas. Each sugar is completely broken down into its individual compounds down to the smallest compound, glucose. The glucose is absorbed in the small intestine via the SGLT1 transporter and passed on to the blood via GLUT-2 transporters. Fructose is absorbed in the intestine via GLUT-5 transporters. The increased blood glucose level also stimulates the GLUT-2 transporters of the pancreas and thus the release of insulin, which in turn stimulates the relocation of the GLUT-4 transporters to the plasma membrane of the muscle cells via insulin receptors in the cell membrane and enables glucose uptake. However, the glucose transporter also shifts during increased physical activity, which ensures the supply of energy to the muscle despite low insulin levels. The calcium concentration in the cell and the plasma level of AMPK play a particularly important role here. The role of AMPK and its antagonist mTOR in particular will be dealt with separately in the section on intermittent fasting. Glucose from food is metabolized to ATP in two stages, both aerobically and anaerobically. In this process, 1 g of carbohydrates has an energy value of 4 kcal. Chapter: Storage of carbohydrates A high concentration of insulin in the blood stimulates glycogen synthesis and is associated with reduction in blood glucose levels: the glucose that is not directly metabolized can be synthesized into glycogen in the hepatocytes of the liver and the myocytes of the skeletal muscles. Glycogen is used to provide energy during anaerobic stress phases and is often used as an energy store for "final sprints". During long periods of endurance exercise, the aim is not to use glycogen stores exclusively for energy production. The oxidation of fat plays a key role here. It is particularly important to note that the storage capacity of glycogen in the liver and muscles is limited and therefore not infinitely available during athletic performance. Approx. 410 kcal can be stored in the liver and approx. 1230-2050 kcal in the muscles. In grams, this is between 350-700g in the muscles, 80-120g in the liver and 4-5g in the bloodstream. In particular, the storage capacity as well as the replenishment of glycogen in the muscles depends on the endurance training status as well as the immediate diet on the days before the competition. A permanently low-carbohydrate diet can quickly lead to a reduction in storage capacity, whereas a temporary low-carbohydrate diet with accompanying training and a subsequent high-carbohydrate diet leads to an optimized replenishment of glycogen stores. However, it is important to know that only the glycogen of the working muscles is available for athletic performance. HYROX is a full-body sport, but running takes up at least 50% of the competition time. For doubles it is even up to 70%. The aerobic part of the metabolism in running is the highest compared to most other workouts. Optimizing the glycogen stores in the running-specific muscles is therefore the basis for an optimal competition result. This increase in storage capacity can only be achieved by running itself. Insulin is a peptide hormone from the pancreas and the natural antagonist of glucagon. Glucagon is a hormone from the liver that causes blood sugar levels to rise. Insulin binds to corresponding receptors on the cell surface of liver, muscle and fatty tissue and accelerates glucose uptake (as well as amino acid, triglyceride and potassium uptake) into the cells. The release of insulin stimulates glycogen synthesis, which stores the "excess" food energy in the muscles and liver. Insulin has a particularly inhibitory effect on gluconeogenesis in the liver and lipolysis (mobilization of the body's own fat). Due to its muscle-building properties, insulin is also misused as an anabolic agent. An excess of insulin in the blood can cause hypoglycemia, which can lead to unconsciousness and death. For this reason, when training clients with type 1 diabetes, blood glucose levels must be checked regularly and communication regarding the administration of insulin is essential. Carbohydrates are the body's primary source of energy and provide athletes with sufficient energy during exercise. As the glycogen storage capacity of the liver (approx. 410 kcal) and muscles (approx. 1230-2050 kcal) is limited, the stores are only sufficient for a duration of 75-90 minutes during anaerobic exercise. Despite strategies such as "carbohydrate loading" or increasing carbohydrate intake in the week before the competition (with a simultaneous reduction in training) to replenish glycogen stores, the intake of carbohydrate combinations during long (>90 minutes) endurance exercise is recommended. In order to prevent hypoglycemia (low blood sugar levels) during exercise and the resulting drop in performance or even termination of exercise and to ensure optimum performance over the entire exercise period, a certain amount of carbohydrates should be consumed over the exercise period of more than 90 minutes. It is also known that a combination of different carbohydrates and their transport mechanisms can be beneficial during prolonged exercise lasting over 2.5 hours. Chapter: The path of glucose into the cell Let's take a closer look at the pathway of glucose from the blood into the muscle cell. There are three different ways in which glucose enters the cell. These three pathways can be differentiated as "push", "pull" and "by contraction": "Push" describes the pathway via the hormone insulin. This hormone, which is secreted by the pancreatic Langhan cells, activates the GLUT4 transporters to become membrane-bound by docking onto the insulin receptors of the cell membrane and thus transporting the blood glucose into the muscle cell. This pathway is therefore dependent on insulin on the one hand and on the sensitivity of the cells' insulin receptors and their number on the other. In the case of insulin resistance (precursor to type 2 diabetes), for example, the sensitivity or already the number of insulin receptors may have decreased. This makes it more difficult or, in the worst case, even completely blocks the pathway for insulin to get the blood sugar into the cell. Triggers for this can include a high food frequency, stress or an activated immune system. "Pull" describes the path of sugar into the cell with the help of activated AMP-kinase (AMPK). The concentration of the AMPK-protein in the muscle cell increases as soon as a certain energy emergency is reached in the cell. This can occur as a result of sporting activity or a longer period of fasting, as with intermittent fasting. This AMPK activity also leads to GLUT4 transporters being synthesized in the cell membrane, allowing sugar to enter the cell independently of insulin. A fasting period of 12 hours (preferably 18 hours) already leads to an increase in the formation of insulin receptors and therefore the "push" pathway works better again. "Contraction" - Muscle contraction can also lead to the GLUT4 transporters becoming membrane-bound. The glucose transporters are pushed into the membrane by the muscle contraction. This pathway of glucose uptake into the muscle cell is therefore also independent of insulin and insulin receptors. It becomes clear that particularly the insulin-independent pathways "pull" and "contraction" play a crucial role in glucose uptake into the muscle cell. The independence from the hormone insulin leads to a significantly improved flexibility of the muscle cell for the uptake of energy in the form of glucose and thus to a possible performance enhancement in competition. But also from a purely health perspective, this is of enormous importance regarding the significantly reduced potential for the development of insulin resistance, the precursor to type 2 diabetes, as well as type 2 diabetes itself. Chapter: Good sources of carbohydrates The glycemic index plays an important role in the choice of carbohydrate-rich foods and the choice of the optimum time for food intake. The glycemic index is defined as the area under the blood glucose curve after consuming 50 g of carbohydrates from various foods compared to the increase with 50 g of pure glucose. It therefore reflects the effect that the corresponding food or a specific sugar compound has on blood sugar. The glycaemic index is expressed as a percentage. Low: <55%, moderate: 55-70%, high: 70-100%. Here are a few examples: *Glucose = 100 *Sucrose = approx. 60 *Spaghetti = approx. 50 *Legumes = approx. 30 The main sources of carbohydrates are fruit, cereal products, potatoes, pulses and vegetables. Other important criteria when choosing foods are the fiber, vitamin, mineral and trace element content, the content of important secondary plant substances and the glycemic load of a food. The glycaemic load not only takes into account the quality of the carbohydrate source, but also the quantity in the corresponding food (GI*CH g per 100 g LM). In other words, how high the proportion of carbohydrates in the selected food is. Both should be taken into account when making a choice and are always in the context of the time of food intake. Chapter: Summary Efficiency and Technique: *Rope management: Avoid dropping the rope by feeding it through your hands as you walk backward. *Pull technique: Choose between arm over arm (slightly faster) or walk back (more efficient for heavier weights). *Muscle group isolation: Train seated, on one knee, or standing to target specific muscles. Alternative Exercises: *Bent-over rows: Work your back and arms. *Pendlay rows: Target back muscles. *Use barbell or dumbbells for these exercises. Tips for Female Athletes: *Remember that sled pull is a slower station than sled push. *Build confidence and encourage clients to take on the challenge. *Use chalk to improve grip and prevent slipping. Chapter: The biomechanical perspective As you have to remain in the box while pulling the sled, the natural inclination is to rely predominantly on the upper body to maintain momentum. This often involves leaning back with a slightly offset stance, allowing the rope to be continuously fed behind. However, most athletes may not have the upper body strength required for this approach, and it’s worth noting that this is not necessarily the most efficient technique. A more effective strategy is to engage the entire body to overcome the sled’s inertia. By leaning back against a taut rope and extending the hips, you can initiate the sled's movement. As it starts to move, complete the pull with knee extension and elbow flexion, then reach forward for more rope and repeat. The friction between your shoes and the surface will dictate how far back you can lean, making the choice of footwear an important consideration for optimizing this exercise.

Chapter: Summary Efficiency is Key • Avoid pushing full 12.5-meter lengths to minimize lactic acid buildup. • Break at halfway points to conserve energy. • Vary positions to prevent muscle fatigue and improve transition. Proper Form and Positioning Position 1 • Grip the sled 3–4 inches below the top of the poles. • Maintain a tight body, engage lats, and brace core. • Push off through the calves. Position 2 • Step into the sled with chest over the weights. • Activate glutes and maintain an upright posture for easier breathing. • Avoid lifting the sled base off the ground. Coaching Tips • Program sled push workouts using time domains (e.g., 60 seconds push, 2 minutes rest) due to varying sled weights. • Incorporate compromise running to simulate race-day conditions. • Vary distances and weights to build power and muscular endurance. • Include high-rep exercises (leg press, back squats, Romanian rhythm squats) for muscular endurance. • Emphasize discipline and efficiency during sled push workouts. Alternatives and Female Considerations • Use walking Zurcher lunges or Zurcher squats if a sled is unavailable. • Build confidence in female athletes by training with heavy weights. • Encourage a strong mindset to overcome the initial challenge of pushing heavy loads. Chapter: The biomechanical perspective This workout demands the most raw strength, requiring the athlete to push an object that is often heavier than their own body weight. The effective transfer of force from the feet through to the sled necessitates a firm and stable trunk and upper body. There are two prominent techniques observed: one involves keeping the elbows highly flexed and tucked into the sides of the trunk, pushing with a horizontal forearm, while the other sees the athlete leaning further over the sled, using a vertical forearm for contact. As discussed in Module 2, athletes must adopt a position that maximizes horizontal push force without leaning down on the sled, which would increase its weight and sliding friction. It can be beneficial to drive slightly upward if done at an appropriate angle, as this can enhance horizontal push force, though this is also influenced by the grip provided by the athlete's shoes. For greater efficiency, the thigh should not recover beyond a vertical position, and maintaining shorter step lengths helps to sustain momentum.

Step up to fingertips, jump forward. • One-knee technique: Easier for larger or heavier athletes. Allows for breaks on each jump. Chapter: The biomechanical perspective As easy as it looks, the Burpee Broad Jump workout is technically quite demanding. To avoid any penalties, the 80-meter distance must be covered primarily through the double-leg broad jump, ensuring that the hand position does not advance more than a foot length in front of the feet. While taller athletes may have a slight advantage, the length of each broad jump largely depends on the athlete’s leg power and the effectiveness of their triple extension through the hip, knee, and ankle joints. With anywhere from 50 to 100 or more repetitions, muscular endurance in both the upper and lower body is crucial. For biomechanical efficiency, the focus should be on developing a consistent rhythm rather than attempting maximum distance with each jump. Incorporating an arm swing can increase vertical impulse by about 10%, which enhances leg muscle loading and further benefits from the stretch-shorten cycle. Additionally, maintaining flexibility to bring the feet back to the hand position ensures that no distance is lost with each jump, optimizing overall performance.

content: Titel: Level 1 - Module 6.2 - Summary URL: https://web.lemon-mobile-learning.com/hyrox/#/inhalt/18020 Chapter: Injury Considerations In the context of HYROX, where athletes often push to their physical limits across a series of demanding workouts, understanding and mitigating the risk of injury is crucial for sustained performance and success. Injuries occur when the force exerted on biological tissues exceeds their tolerance levels, causing fibers to stretch beyond their limits and tear. The prevention of such injuries in athletes hinges on two primary biomechanical factors: *stress*, which refers to the amount of eccentric force and the rate at which force is accepted, and *strain*, which is the excessive elongation of muscle fibers. These factors are further influenced by the number of contractions, or repetitions, and the onset of fatigue, where the muscle’s capacity to generate or absorb force becomes compromised. Athletes often fall into the trap of pushing themselves too hard, too quickly, under the outdated “no pain, no gain” mentality. However, tissues require time to adapt and build resilience, making effective recovery strategies crucial. To mitigate injury risks and enhance performance, athletes should focus on several key strategies: developing eccentric strength to manage force loads, enhancing elastic strength through plyometric training to improve the rate of force loading, and ensuring appropriate joint mobility for each exercise to maintain flexibility. Additionally, planning the number of repetitions and gradually increasing load capacity helps build endurance while reducing injury risks. Finally, implementing a comprehensive recovery plan—incorporating rest, mobilization, therapy, nutritional support, and varied training—enables tissues to recover and adapt effectively. Chapter: Summary When training for individual HYROX workouts or integrating them into combined sessions, it’s essential to deeply consider the performance capabilities, or Zubringerleistungen, required for each exercise. While these workouts may serve as valuable training routines for the general gym population, they take on a different significance for competitive HYROX athletes, where they become critical elements of a comprehensive event. This requires a strategic approach to training, where each workout is not only optimized for peak performance in isolation but also carefully considered in the context of how it fits into the overall race strategy. In designing these training sessions, it’s crucial to apply the principles covered in Module 2 and Module 3, ensuring that each session is tailored to address the specific demands of each workout. From a biomechanical perspective, HYROX is an endurance-based race, with each exercise requiring distinct techniques and targeted muscle group engagement. The efficiency of muscle force generation is key, with a focus on optimizing the direction of force application, proper trunk positioning relative to gravity, and the development of elastic qualities to enhance performance and minimize injury risk. Furthermore, the frictional interaction between shoes and surfaces, particularly during sled exercises, is vital for effective force production, making footwear grip an important consideration.

Chapter: Summary Efficiency is Key • The overriding theme for all videos is efficiency. • While faster times can be achieved with higher dampener settings, it’s less efficient for longer workouts. Proper Form and Positioning • Stand 18–24 inches back from the flywheel, feet shoulder-width apart. • Experiment with dampener settings between 3 and 6 to find your optimal setting. • Begin the stroke with a 2–3.25 stroke, followed by a half stroke and then a full stroke. • Engage lats, brace core, hinge through hips, and drive body weight through the stroke. • Inhale at the reach and exhale during the drive. • Avoid full squatting, as it can negatively impact performance. Coaching Tips • Emphasize the importance of efficient skiing for smooth transitions. • Maintain a stroke rate of 35–45 for optimal power and breathing. • Incorporate strength training for triceps, lats, abs, hip flexors, and calves. • Train across all three energy systems (lactic anaerobic, aerobic) for well-rounded development. • On race day, slow down the 1000m by 15–20 seconds to facilitate a smoother transition. Considerations for Females • May need to rely more on calves due to anatomical differences. • May require a slightly higher stroke rate to compensate for lower weight. • Bands can be used as an alternative if a SkiErg is unavailable. Chapter: The biomechanical perspective In this part of the course, we will focus on applying fundamental biomechanical principles to specific HYROX activities, with the goal of enhancing performance, executing movements more efficiently, and reducing the risk of injuries. The 1000m Ski, in particular, can be performed using sound biomechanical principles to improve efficiency and minimize the risk of shoulder injuries: 1.Stance and Positioning: Adopt a wide stance for enhanced stability, positioning your heels as far back on the platform as possible while maintaining good shoulder extension with partial shoulder flexion. This setup optimizes the range of motion needed for an effective pull. 2.Initiating the Pull: Begin the pull by engaging in trunk/hip flexion and knee flexion, keeping the shoulders and elbows fixed. This allows gravity to assist in overcoming the flywheel's inertia, making the initial movement more efficient. 3.Executing the Pull: While bracing the core and keeping the elbows locked, flex the shoulders to pull down and back, and complete the movement by extending the elbows and wrists, guiding the cables toward your thighs. This proximal-to-distal sequencing ensures a smooth and powerful pull. 4.Recovery Phase: For an efficient recovery, keep the movement in the sagittal plane, following the most direct path back to the starting position. Avoid the “butterfly” motion by reversing the order of the pull—starting with elbow flexion, followed by shoulder extension, hip extension, and knee extension. 5.Resistance and Efficiency: Set an appropriate resistance that allows you to balance distance per stroke (force) with stroke rate (velocity). You should feel some initial resistance at the start of each pull, which indicates that the resistance is set correctly for your performance needs. By incorporating these principles into the 1000m Ski technique, the athlete can enhance overall efficiency and significantly reduce the likelihood of injury, particularly to the shoulders.

Chapter: The biomechanical perspective When rowing on an ergometer, there are three key points of contact: the feet, the seat, and the hands on the handle. The goal is to efficiently transfer all muscular effort into the handle by selecting a resistance level that balances distance per stroke with stroke frequency. The rowing motion is a coordinated effort involving both a push from the legs (leg drive) and a pull with the arms, all of which are connected and stabilized by the torso. In the starting position, with the trunk leaning forward, knees flexed, and arms extended with a relaxed, cupped grip on the handle, the initial leg drive must be synchronized with a pull on the handle. The trunk acts as a stable platform to effectively transfer the power generated by the legs to the handle. A common mistake is allowing the seat to move backward without corresponding movement of the handle, indicating a loss of connection between the leg drive and the upper body pull. As momentum builds in the handle, the hips extend, and the trunk leans back while the shoulders and elbows remain extended. The rowing stroke is completed as the handle is pulled into the chest. The recovery phase should be relaxed and take as long as the drive, reversing the order of movements: first extending the elbows, then flexing the trunk, and finally allowing the knees to flex only after the handle has passed beyond them. The handle should follow a straight path throughout. If the resistance at the start feels minimal, the setting is likely too low; conversely, if the biceps are overly engaged, the resistance may be set too high. Proper resistance ensures that the entire body contributes effectively to the rowing stroke, optimizing performance.

Chapter: The biomechanical perspective The challenge with the Farmer's Carry lies in making the exercise as relaxed and efficient as possible. It is crucial to avoid overstriding, as placing the foot too far in front of or behind the center of mass increases the demand on postural control and pelvic stability. This process can be broken down into three distinct phases: 1. The Countermovement: Involves flexing the hips and knees to lower the center of mass, ensuring the hips descend below the knees. 2. The Leg Drive: Entails extending the hips and knees from the lowest position to full extension, propelling the body upward. 3. The Ball Drive: Involves accelerating the ball upwards from the chest to the point of release. Executing the countermovement and leg drive as a continuous motion triggers the stretch-shortening cycle, which enhances the acceleration of both the body and the ball. This stretch-shortening enhancement is optimized through targeted eccentric strength and plyometric training. The timing of the ball drive is crucial; it should seamlessly follow the leg drive to fully capitalize on the momentum generated. Any pause between the squat and ball drive will disrupt this momentum, making it more challenging for the athlete to reach the target height.

content: Titel: Level 1 - Module 7 - Phases of Training URL: https://web.lemon-mobile-learning.com/hyrox/#/inhalt/18000 Chapter: Phases of Training The strategic division of an athlete's training program into distinct phases is a hallmark of periodization. These phases, each with specific objectives and training focuses, collectively contribute to the athlete's peak performance. This chapter outlines the primary phases of training—General Preparation, Specific Preparation, Pre-Competition, Competition, and Transition—drawing on the expertise of sports scientists to highlight their significance and application. The General Preparation Phase (GPP) lays the foundation for subsequent training phases, emphasizing the development of a broad base of conditioning, strength, and technical skills. Bompa & Carrera (2015) emphasize the importance of this phase, stating, "The GPP is crucial for building the athlete’s capacity for work and preparing the body for the stresses of more intense, specific training." During this phase, athletes engage in a variety of general conditioning activities designed to improve overall fitness and resilience. Following the GPP, the Specific Preparation Phase (SPP) involves more focused training activities that are closely related to the athlete's sport-specific demands. This phase aims to translate the general capacities developed in the GPP into sport-specific skills and performance capabilities. Zatsiorsky & Kraemer (2006) note, "The SPP is where athletes begin to refine their abilities in a manner that is directly applicable to their sport, focusing on specific energy systems and technical skills." The Pre-Competition Phase serves as a bridge between the SPP and the Competition Phase, fine-tuning the athlete's form and ensuring readiness for competition. It involves the integration of competition-specific strategies and mental preparation. According to Stone et al. (2007), "This phase is critical for the psychological and technical preparation of the athlete, optimizing performance levels through simulation of competitive environments." The Competition Phase is when the athlete applies their training in actual competitive situations. The focus shifts to maintaining peak performance, with minimal increases in fitness. Muller et al. (2015) describe this phase as "a period characterized by high-intensity, low-volume training designed to maximize performance while reducing the risk of overtraining." Example: During competition, the soccer player's training would be tailored to recovery and tactical adjustments based on upcoming opponents, with an emphasis on maintaining peak physical and psychological state. Post-competition, athletes enter the Transition Phase, also known as the off-season or recovery phase. This period allows for physical and psychological recovery from the demands of training and competition. Bompa & Buzzichelli (2019) highlight its necessity, stating, "The transition phase is essential for mental rest, recovery, and preparation for the next training cycle, preventing burnout and overtraining." And anyone who's ever played a sport—whether it’s basketball, soccer, or track and field—knows the feeling: sometimes you just want to mix things up, take a little break from your usual routine. It’s like hitting the reset button so that when the new season rolls around, you're pumped and ready to tackle new challenges, ideas, and training methods to boost your performance. Incorporating these phases into the training program enables athletes to systematically progress towards peak performance, with each phase building upon the last. The strategic manipulation of training focus, intensity, and volume throughout these phases ensures the athlete's development is optimized, culminating in peak performance for competition. This section will delve into the unique challenges and considerations for designing periodized training programs across these two broad categories, drawing on expert insights and literature to illustrate key points.

Chapter: History of Periodization of Training The concept of periodization in sports has its origins in the early 20th century, but it was during the mid-1900s that it truly began to take shape, thanks to the groundbreaking work of Eastern European scientists and coaches. Figures like Russian physiologist Leo Matveyev, Hungarian coaches István Javorek were instrumental in refining periodization as a sophisticated, adaptable framework for optimizing athletic training. These pioneers recognized the limitations of generic training programs and introduced periodization as a method to tailor training regimens to the individual needs and goals of athletes. Historically, periodization was more than just a method for organizing training; it represented a holistic approach to athletic development. By strategically varying key training variables—such as intensity, volume, and specificity—periodization was designed to prevent performance plateaus, reduce the risk of overuse injuries, and ensure continual progress. This systematic approach enabled athletes to develop a range of physiological systems, including endurance, strength, speed, and agility, thereby ensuring comprehensive physical preparedness for competition. Today, the principles of periodization continue to evolve, thanks to the contributions of contemporary sports scientists and experts like Tudor Bompa, often referred to as the "father of periodization" in the Western world, and Vladimir Issurin, a leading authority on block periodization. Istvan Balyi is also widely recognized for his work on the Long-Term Athlete Development (LTAD) model, which integrates periodization principles to guide athletes from early development through to peak performance. This is a special topic which we will cover in the HYROX365 Academy Level 2 course “HYROX Youngstars”. In recent years, researchers like Greg Haff and Mike Stone have made significant contributions to the field. Greg Haff has focused on the practical applications of periodization in strength and conditioning, particularly within resistance training. Mike Stone, known for his work in strength and power development, has contributed extensively to the understanding of how periodization impacts athletic performance and adaptation.
